Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2011 12:29AM jenn3 wrote: It's hard to say how you will feel, we each have different feelings about this.  I had a BMX in June 2009.  The surgery was much, much easier than I thought.  I never cried or mourned the loss of my breast.  I've gotten used to the new look and so has DH.  I wear breast prosthesis when I go to work or out of the house and take them off when I'm home.  I don't wear them when I'm lounging around the house, walking or doing yard work. One hint, when I took a shower I used a wide ribbon tied around my neck hanging down to attach the drains to so that my hands would be free to move in the shower.  Good luck!!!
Posts.Title: how to mentally prepare for a mx? --- ---

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2009 09:29PM jenn3 wrote: Although I do believe in the mammograms - as mine did confirm what I found.  I am the first person in my family to have cancer on either side, and have had no one close to me have cancer of any kind so I really didn't know much about it.  I had a mammogram in August 07, skipped follow up in 08 because my youngest daughter was very ill and I was spending most of my free time trying to get her properly dx'd (story worse than mine).  However, in June of 08 I had a regular appt in which I had a check by my dr and nothing was there - and I didn't feel a thing doing my self exams.   While I was recovering (laid up in bed) from a torn achilles at the end of March 09 I found the lump, but forgot about it until May when it started to hurt.  I did research and learned that cancer doesn't hurt and decided not to call the dr because I knew I had a mammogram appt a month later.  As for the lymph nodes I had no idea.  Looking back the pain I had under my arm when I leaned on my crutches while standing was not the crutches hitting nerves it was the lymph nodes - because when the dr touched under my arms it sent me to the ceiling. In my case my onc can't say for sure, but he believes it was linked to the RH drugs I started taking in Oct 08.  He had just written a paper on the link between Humira and Breast Cancer, then shortly after my surgery it was all over the news with warnings.  I had no idea - my sister found the warning literally at the bottom of the page in smaller print.  I do believe we need better screenings - as my sister has very large dense breast and has to fight for more testing.  However, education in so many forms is needed.  First -cancer does hurt-terribly!  And..... is my cancer a result of the medication - I'll never know, but had I understood the warnings I feel like I could have made a decision based on all of the information - would I have still taken it - I don't know.  The onc told me that when medicaitons warn us that our immune systems will be compromised it doesn't just mean from viral and bacterial infections.  It also means that our bodies will not be able to fight cancer cells and other illnesses that attack our cellular system and organs.  I honestly had no idea that a compromised immune system meant it opened me up to cancer. We need better screening, teach self exams and education in so many ways.  We also need to make sure that we know we can question our doctors if we're not comfortable or change doctors.  As my grandfather used to say it's the practice of medicine - not an exact science.  This is not related to mammograms, but I have to share - the side in which I have cancer is the side that hair has never grown under the arm.  Is that a link of some sort?  Probably not, but strange.........

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2010 07:25PM jenn3 wrote: Lisa - you will get used to the port.  I had mine put in during my surgery (bi-lat mx).  At first I noticed all of the time, it was even a little sore.  Then after my first chemo and ER visit and I realized how easy it was to access - I was sold on the port.  I didn't even use the numbing spray, I thought the freezing spray had a sting to it that lasted longer than the quick stick of the needle used to access the port.  As the months past, there were times I forgot I had it. Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2011 05:21AM jenn3 wrote: I hope that you feel better soon.  If you aren't already taking regular doses of Miralax or Benefiber, something to keep things moving, it would be a good idea.  There could be a small twist or small blockage even though you're still moving, from constipation up in those intestines causing pain.  Also, try writing down what you eat everyday to see if there is a correlation between the food and pain.  Could you be slightly lactose intolerant?  It can come on without warning to people that have never been lactose intolerant.  The pain from eating dairy can hurt like nobody's business. I hope that you feel better soon and get find the answers ((((hugs)))) Jenn

Posts.Content: May 17, 2011 08:39PM jenn3 wrote: I had a BMX at stage III and have not regreted my decision.  I don't know what I would have done had I been in your position.  The surgery itself was probably one of the easier surgeries I've had.  The drains were annoying, but not painful and the pain from the surgery wasn't nearly as bad as I thought.  I am okay living without breast, but there are times I miss them and would like to have clothes fit better, but overall I'm good with my prosthesis.  And.....hell I get to take my boobs off at the end of the day. Right before I was dx'd (3 months) with my Stage IV dx I was talking to my onc about recon.  He could tell that I really wasn't mentally ready for another big surgery, one that would involve recovery time when I was feeling great.  He suggested I wait until I'm mentally - 100% ready to face surgery.  I am glad that I waited because of my dx 3 months later, but what he was telling me was that I needed to be ready and if there was any doubt - WAIT. If you make the decision to have surgery, ask the surgeon the "clean up" the dog ears left after a BMX, if you're not doing recon.  It's extra skin and tissue left under the arm areas, all women have it.  When we have breast it is not noticable because our breast naturally pull the tissue and skin forward.  Mine doesn't look bad and it doesn't show when I'm dressed, but it just annoys me.  Good luck with your decision, it's a hard one to make, but I know the right one will come to you soon.  (((hugs))) Jenn

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2011 09:01AM jenn3 wrote: You're in a tough place.  If it were my Mom I would drive or fly to my Mom's next appointment to discuss the dx, treatment and at your Mom's age is the treatment going to be harder on her than doing no treatment.  Also, make sure she has given the doctor permission to talk to you so that you can call him/her when necessary or when you have questions.  My FIL has cancer, but it is very slow moving and causing no pain so he and my MIL elected to not have treatment - QOL is more important.  It's been almost 2 years since his dx and...........he really is doing great and at times I forget he has cancer.  I know that your Mom has trouble with her vision, which does make a difference in the treatment plan, but I just wanted to let you know what we're going through with my FIL. Radiation is very exhausting and between that, ativan and her age is why she is probably sleeping so much, but again this would be converstation to have with the doctor. Good luck and I'm sorry you have to go through this.  ((((hugs)))) Jenn

Posts.Title: THAT STUNG.................. jenn3 jenn3

Posts.Content: jenn3 wrote: Today I woke up feeling down, no particular reason, just a down day.  It happens, a bad day here and there - I'll get through it.  But.... today wasn't just a bad day - my feelings got hurt for the first time in a really long time by people who really don't matter, but it hurt. I forgot to bring my lunch with me to work so I ran over to Subway - getting ready to check out and the man behind the counter looks up and says "How may I help you Sir, Ma'am, Sir, Ma'am".  He was busy, I understand - I have very, very short hair and was wearing a black trench coat over my black suit. Although it caught me off guard and was my first Sir, I was okay after the little sting of hearing Sir for the first time. Then........... about 2 hours later a client I haven't seen in years walked by my desk - I was busy, looked up smiled at him and he looked at me with that I know you, but why look.  As he was walking out he glanced at my nameplate, which told him who I was - I used to talk to him daily for years, so at that point he knew who I was.  He leaned over to my co-worker and whispered "WHAT HAPPENED TO HERRRRRRR".  Yes, he did that loud whisper thing.  Ouch - that hurt my feelings.  Bigger sting - two in one day. Tearing up as I type this, but I just needed to say it to people who understand.    Yes, my hair is extremely short - still growing out, but really - keep the comments to yourself or at the very least, keep them away from me.  Guess I'll go home take a good walk - hot shower and hope to wake up on the right side of the bed tomorrow. Jenn - June 2009 IDC-TN, Stage III, 02/2011 Stage IV mets to the lungs & spine / Laugh until your belly hurts, then laugh some more........... Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2010 06:06PM jenn3 wrote: I made Potato and Leek soup for dinner tonight, it was delicious  4-5 yukon gold potatoes (I used regular potatoes) - cut into 1/2 inch pieces 4 large leeks chopped (using only the white and pale green parts) 1 onion chopped 1 tsp fresh garlic 6 cups low sodium chicken broth 1/2 tsp pepper 3/4 cup chopped (small) ham - optional Clean leeks by cutting off the end and tops, slice lengthwise and soak in bowl for a few minutes. Put all of the above in a pot, bring to a boil and simmer for 25 minutes.  Then transfer to blender (in batches) and puree.  We added the ham to the soup after it was pureed, then simmered on the stove for another 10 minutes and found it added a little more flavor.

Posts.Content: jenn3 wrote: As I posted on another thread I am dealing with a lot of pain from the lesion on my T8 spine.  I've had back pain off and on for over 10 years, but never this debilitating.  It's always been something I could live with - meaning controlled by medicine, time, rest, exercise, etc.  This pain is so different.  I know that part of the problem has been me..........I let it get out of control before addressing the issue.  I think I realized that today for the first time.  Drove to work Took pain meds Felt loopy (trying to think - ugh) Pain started to kick in again 3 hours later Checked my watch - took only 1/2 a pill because I had to drive in 5 hours 2 hours later the pain was so bad I left and came home By the time I came home I was in so much pain there are no words Took 2 pain pills, dosed off and on for 3 hours, took more meds.... It took 8 hours to get the pain under control - 8 hours.  I am now taking pain meds every three hours no matter what and............the pain is finally under control.  OMG - this is a lot of pain medication.  Is this what I will have to live with?  I want to work, drive and continue to do as much as I can, but am worried I'll be on pain meds for the rest of my life.  I am meeting with the rad onc tomorrow, he works closely with my onc and is down the hall from him - I'm sure he'll work with me to help get the pain under control with rads. Then I see my onc again on Wed and I'm sure he'll change my meds again, but I am worried.  Does it get better - pain wise?  Will my body have to adjust to all of the pain medication?  I can't imagine living in a loopy world "forever"....... It's 4am, I'm rambling because of the pain meds, can't sleep and am due for more medication in an hour..........thanks for listening, reading and being there. Jenn Jenn - June 2009 IDC-TN, Stage III, 02/2011 Stage IV mets to the lungs & spine / Laugh until your belly hurts, then laugh some more........... Log in to post a reply

On the upside, the weather is beautiful today.  The sky is a beautiful blue, no clouds with a slight breeze, just enough to gentle move the windchimes.  The birds are making their homes in the bird houses I have hanging, they're eating and drinking, singing and make for good entertainment.  Meanwhile my dogs have decided to sun bathe outside in the yard..........I love days like these.

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2011 10:21AM jenn3 wrote: I don't have much experience with Xeloda, but did take it for a short time before moving to Gemzar/Carbo.  My short lived experience of 2 -3  weeks on Xeloda came with no SE's.  From what I understand is that Xeloda is tolerated well by most people.  There are a few people that it doesn't agree with, but overall it's an okay drug.  I've read, heard from others and from my onc that the most bothersome SE is hand and foot syndrome.  The palms of your hands and bottoms of feet become very tender, blister and can be uncomfortable.  I put vaseline on both my hands and feet every night of the 2 -3 weeks I was on Xeloda and had no problems, but then again I was only on it for a little while and it hadn't had time to accumulate in my system.  I also read that Aquafor or other heavy creams work best on the hands and feet rather than a thinner lotion. Good luck  -  Jenn

You CAN do this - you will be walking along the beach next year thinking this wasn't as hard as you thought......................

Posts.Content: jenn3 wrote: I have the personality of handle the situation you're in, don't feel sorry for yourself and laugh if you can.  Strangely enough I have managed to get through all of this w/o anxiety or depression medications, no sleep aids other than benadryl and with my head held high, laughing, joking and taking it as it comes.  I have had some bad days, but that was it, just a few bad days and I can usually bounce back. However, I've think somewhere lurking under all of my strong exterior and joking are some really pent up emotions.  I find that I've become overly sensitive to comments made to me about my hair growing, surgeries or progress.  Today while having a follow up MRI for an ongoing back problem rather than just laying there as I usually do thinking about what I'll do that day or working out thoughts I had these terrible visions of little cancer cells invading my body,  my heart started to beat fast and I started breathing really fast.  Thank goodness I was pulled out before I had a full blown panic attack.   I've noticed I'm becoming teary eyed at little things and nervous about my upcoming 1 year cancerversary. I normally have no problem talking about what I've been through and the importance of self exams as well as mammograms.  But lately, I just don't want to talk about, hear the word cancer or references to what I've been through.  The closer I get to my 1 yr cancerversary -I feel like I'm trying to run away - escape it as if it never happened.  None of my family, friends or co-workers know I'm feeling blah!!!  They think I'm fine, continue to want to talk about "it", comment on my hair, consults with various recon drs, etc.  On the outside I guess I appear fine, but on the inside I'm a mess. I know I'll get through this we all do..............but, I feel as if I should be happier as I near the one year mark.  Instead I'm feeling blue................... Jenn - June 2009 IDC-TN, Stage III, 02/2011 Stage IV mets to the lungs & spine / Laugh until your belly hurts, then laugh some more........... Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: jenn3 wrote: I have shingles................when is it enough?  Or, does being a cancer patient mean it's never over, it's always going to be one thing after the other? I was changing clothes from my comfy hang around the house clothes to I am leaving the house clothes.  When DD#2 notices red blotches all over my back and side.  The timing was good, I was getting ready to leave to head over the drs office for my neulasta shot.  Perfect timing......when I got there I asked the nurse, she in turn went to get the dr.  He came in looked a my back and side and said it did look like shingles.  He also said it could be the reason for the intense pain I had, saying a lot of times the pain rears its ugly head before the redness or blisters.  It just so happens to be in the area I've been having trouble with.  I was given some medicine and told to call and give an update and/or call if things get really bad or too much to handle. I guess it's a wait and see game at this point.   I tell you, I feel like I live in a never ending cycle.  Well, I'm off to watch Survivor - talk to y'all later.  Jenn Jenn - June 2009 IDC-TN, Stage III, 02/2011 Stage IV mets to the lungs & spine / Laugh until your belly hurts, then laugh some more........... Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2009 02:39AM jenn3 wrote: When I was initially dx I was worried that I wouldn't be here for my family.  Then when TN dx came - my fears became worse - thinking I had even less time.   Then........... somewhere along the way I decided to get out of that thought process and enjoy each minute.  I quit reading the negative stuff on TN, haven't looked at a statistic in months and quite asking the onc for my prognosis.  Besides he always says it good and to live my life - he wouldn't feed into my need for the years I had left. After learning more about BC, my odds are as good as anyone.  And............... even before breast cancer I hated statistics because I felt and still feel they can be manipuated and have flaws.  I say don't look at the statistics and tell yourself you have a very long time ahead of you......
Posts.Title: Venting..... Pure HairSprayMom

Posts.Content: jenn3 wrote: I am on round two of my 3 week cycles with Gemzar/Carboplatin (Day 1, Day 8 cycles).  I get neupogen shots after day 1 and neulasta after day 8.  My onc will rescan me after my third round.  My counts are down, I am severly anemic, sleeping tons, short of breath and downright exhausted, but still getting out and about when I'm up, taking care of business, etc.  My onc said that I am 2/10 of a point from needing a blood transfusion, which doesn't make me happy, but we do what we have to.  And............he's already mentioned taking a chemo break if necessary. THAT scares me to no end.  I am TN and it seems everytime a TN takes a chemo break those damn little cancer cells take off and take over - I don't want to take a break.  My DD was with me and in the room on this particular appointment because I didn't expect anything other than a brief run through and then my chemo infusion.  I didn't want to question him too much with DD in the room, so I let it go.  But, next week I plan on having a good long conversation about the transfusion, chemo break and what we could do in lieu of a break because I am TN. Already a break - doesn't that seem early?  I just started chemo in April, a break?  I am terrified of taking a break. Jenn - June 2009 IDC-TN, Stage III, 02/2011 Stage IV mets to the lungs & spine / Laugh until your belly hurts, then laugh some more........... Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: May 15, 2011 09:30PM jenn3 wrote: Be kind to your mouth. 1. Ask your onc for the "magic mouthwash", mine called it Dukes Solution.  It soothes and numbs your mouth so that you can eat and drink.  Be sure to eat meals that are gentle and not too spicy.  And.........gentle salt water or baking soda with water mix will help cleanse and soothe your mouth. 2. Purchase Biotene toothpaste and mouthwash.  It is meant for dry/sore mouths, very gentle and has no alcohol or minty feeling that irritates the sores.  It was a lifesaver for me. 3. Stay away from acidic foods or drinks, spicy or really salty foods. 4. Keep your mouth moist.  You risk infection and other dental/gum problems if your mouth gets to dry.  The saliva helps keep your mouth hydrated and constantly cleanse away germs.  During this time, be sure to sip on water and swich it around your mouth often (incl. nighttime). Good luck and I hope you feel better soon.

Posts.Content: May 25, 2011 04:49PM jenn3 wrote: I too am struggling with extreme fatigue.  It's a level of fatigue unless experienced is really not understood by others.  I know this isn't the the same situation, but similar in that your body needs time to recover.  My DD was in a wheelchair for 3 months, when she was able to start walking again she tired easily.  It took her 6 - 9 months before she felt like herself again.  I remember her doctor telling us the body needs the time to heal and for every one day down it was 2 -3 days recovery.  Give yourself a break and know that you will grow stronger each day.  In addition to the infection which is very hard on your body you're going through chemo. The vacation that was suggested may be just what you need.  Take a break from cancer, chemo and feeling down.  Sometimes even if our bodies are worn out, if we can be mentally revitalized we begin to feel better all over. (((hugs))) Jenn

Posts.Content: May 7, 2010 01:07PM jenn3 wrote: I had about 5 weeks between chemo and radation.  I was told I needed to recover from the chemo before starting radiation (and it was during the holiday season).  However, from what I read that time span seems to be pretty normal - may lean a little either way.  Right before I started radiation I was starting to feel a little better, then towards the end of radiation I was feeling worn down again.  Now that I am about 6 weeks out of radiation I actually feel better than I have in a long time.  I'm starting to feel a little like my old self again.   I agree with Diane - I think our recovery time and ability to bounce back is on an individual basis, just like the SE's from chemo.   Throughout my life I have always been active, but have had periods where I got lazy.  I've always been able to bounce back without too much struggle.  However, I have noticed that I am much weaker (I'm 43) and am working harder to recover muscle tone and stamina.  It gets better...........

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2011 07:48PM jenn3 wrote: I am so sorry you have a cold, nothing like feeling bad on top of everything else........ If you have a stuffy nose, headaches and pain in the face, take a decongestant.  Also, if you have a lot of stuffiness sometimes the Mucinex with a decongestant helps (Mucinex thins, sudafed reduces swelling).  If you're running, take an antihistamine.  I like Zyrtec, but everyone seems to have their favorites.  And.........when all else fails I take one of the nighttime cold medicines like Nyquil, Tylenol Nightime, etc and just sleep.  I hope that you feel better soon (((hugs)))

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2011 08:02PM jenn3 wrote: My first round with chemo I joined a trial which was AC+T, the trial drug was Avastin.  I rec'd the placebo.  I was happy to participate.   I liked the extra monitoring and it gave me a direct line to the nurse and doctor, which was a nice bonus.  However, after a LOT of research I decided I really wasn't crazy about the trials being offered this time and declined for the time being.  Look at the National Cancer Institute's website under clinical trials www.cancer.gov/clinicaltrials   It will help you understand more about the trial you are being offered along with helping you to make decisions.  I also like to look at the drugs being offered under www.chemocare.com as well.

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2010 03:06PM jenn3 wrote: Peverson - I am so sorry you had to join the club that none of us wants to join, but you will find plenty support from the women here. I was diagnosed right after spending two years helping my daughter who had been ill for 2 years with a rare neurological disease. I was 42 when I was diagnosed and was caught off guard with the diagnosis.  It's hard to hear the words you've got cancer and the road your faced with is scary, but you can do it and will get through it.  I also did 4 DD AC followed by 12 Taxol.  Kimber suggested rinsing your mouth to help avoid or minimize possible mouth sores and that is a great suggestion.  I also sucked on ice cubes during the Adriamycin portion of the infusion because I heard that helped.  In addition I used Biotene toothpaste and mouthwash because it was much easier on my mouth during chemo.  I also drank lots of water to help flush my system and stay hydrated - which really helps. And.... like Anacortes said - call your dr if you have a question or something doesn't seem right - they're there to help you get through this and answer all of your questions. I'm sending (((HUGS))) your way........Jenn

Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2011 12:22PM jenn3 wrote: I used Miaderm, Lubiderm and pure aloe - my skin looked beautiful.  It didn't start getting red and only slightly red until the last week.  When rads were finished I continued using lotions and creams, but my skin was still cooking............   It was the week after I finished rads that my skin started to crack and peel.  It leaked and oozed this nasty stuff that is unexplainable and the pain was horrific.  I was told by the nurse that patients that have had a BMX without recon usually have more severe burns because they don't have as much tissue to absord the rays.  Whether or not that is true, that was what they told me (I had a BMX, no recon).  I went into the office for almost a week so that they could clean the burned area, in addition to the cleaning I did.  They also used a wonderful pad that stuck to the skin, absorbed the ooz, but didn't hurt coming off.  I used pain medication and couldn't have made it through that week without it.  With all of that said, I do think I was NOT the norm.
Posts.Title: Is pain medicaton needed for rads bedo 3monstmama

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2011 09:41PM jenn3 wrote: The eye doctor is the one that "discovered" or help us figure out what was wrong with DD#2 years ago.  She had all of the symptoms of a brain tumor, but none of the tests showed a tumor so the doctors ruled her as having mental illness.  Then on a regular eye exam the eye doctor noticed the optic nerve was flat, meaning there was a lot of pressure on the nerve, mimicing a tumor.  She was diagnosed within a week as having Intracranial Hypertension, a rare neurological disease.  Because DD was an active high school cheerleader with no other problems and the symptoms came on suddenly they thought it was mental illness.  Of course looking back there were many signs we didn't notice.  Anyway, it was then that I learned eye exams are the gateway to the brain.  The eye doctor can see a lot through our eyes and a lot of times diagnose tumors on the brain.

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2011 04:02PM jenn3 wrote: Some of the answers to the questions will be with the laws of your state and are you in a community property state.  If the debt is a joint debt, the spouse will have to continue paying the debt. If you have debt when you pass away, the estate is expected to pay the debt first, the remaining funds will go to the heirs.  If there are no heirs and there is no estate, then the bill collectors are SOL.  If you have checking or savings accounts you can have a POD put on the account or make it a joint account with someone you trust or want to give the money to.

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2010 03:18AM jenn3 wrote: Molly - I don't think what you're feeling is wrong, I don't think there is a right or wrong way to feel.  This diagnosis affects us in so many ways and our emotions are all over the place.  I'll bet if you stop and think about it your anger or frustration isn't at the person with a lower stage complaining, it's probably more about what you're going through. I think it's very brave of you to be able to put what you feel out there, because we all have feelings that for some reason don't feel right, we know we shouldn't judge or discard someone else, but it happens.  I just posted something yesterday about helping friends with "suspicious" mammos and being there for them through the biopsies, then feeling hurt or upset when they were given the all clear.  I don't wish cancer on anyone and still don't know why I felt that way, but I did.  Our minds can go places we wish they didn't. (((hugs))) Jenn

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2011 12:34AM jenn3 wrote: Last weekend we had a day filled with sunshine and weather that felt and smelled like spring.  I worked in our yard all morning, then enjoyed the rest of the day running errands, walking, etc.  I knew it was a bad joke because it wasn't going to last...........I was right, it is down right cold, not as cold as my friends in the North, but it's too cold to do much outside and with ice on the roads in some areas we have to be careful - we're not used to that.  The winter blues are hard to shake when you have one bad storm after the other hitting and you can't get outdoors like you want to, especially for someone like you who loves the outdoors.  I'm sorry you're feeling down and I wish I could make it better, in the meantime I'm sending a warm (((hug))) your way.

Jenn  I am terrible with jokes, but do have a funny story to share.  My DD#2 just told me this story two days ago.  My DD#2 attends college in a somewhat rural community, there are a lot of sportsmen, fishing, hunting, etc......  She has never been fishing, nor hunting.  Last year a group of friends decided to fishing off of a dock near campus.  She threw her line out into the water and low and behold she got a hit, a big one.  She of course starts screaming, "I've got a fish", "what do I do".  Her friends screams "bring it in" so not knowing how to bring the fish in she began to run down the dock with the fishing pole.  Needless to say everyone out there started laughing hysterically while trying to tell her to reel it in, not run down the dock and drag the fish out of the water.  I hope that the jokes and funny stories help bring a smile to your face.  More (((hugs)))))

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2010 12:33AM jenn3 wrote: Before I had rec'd my path report and found out I was TN, I had made the decision to do a bi-lat masectomy.   My onc didn't tell me what to do, I had already made up my mind.  But....... he did say when my case was presented to the board it was unanimous they all agreed I should have an immediate bi-lat, with chemo and radation.   I hope that you can find the answer you're looking for, it seems a lot of us go different routes so it's hard to say what's right or wrong.  But what I can say is you need to feel comfortable with the decision you make and with your doctors - yes they should agree and not put you in the middle.  (((HUGS)))) and know you can come here for support.

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2011 01:15PM jenn3 wrote: I think that so many of us deal with stressful situations differently and I am usually put off by people who say we should cope one way or the other.  My sister is more emotional, wears her heart on her sleeve and has told me so many times she doesn't understand why I don't get upset.  Honestly, I don't know why I don't get as wound up, the only answer I can give her is that we all process things differently.  I think that each of us has a coping mechanism and have found ways to process and deal with this and that there isn't one way that is better than the other. Jen - I think you're doing a great job of healing and moving on.  I remember when you first came to the boards you were so upset and it seemed to me that you wanted an answer that wasn't there and now look at you.  You're helping the other newbies, growing your business, traveling and livng your life - I'd say you've done a great job!
Posts.Title: Am I healing or Surpressing Pure kimber3006

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2009 08:49PM jenn3 wrote: I was dx with TN in June, 1.9cm in breast, 4cm and 3 cm in lymph nodes and am being treated aggressively.  My youngest is a senior in high school and our challenges this year are different than yours, but I wanted to let you know it willl work out.  You will get through this.........Since starting chemo I have spent plenty time (weekly) with my cousin's 5 children, one of which is my god-child and they have not gotten me sick.  Don't put your children in daycare if you don't have to, that would actually expose you to more germs than having them home with you.  As my onc always says, no restrictions, be smart.  This is the time to ask for and accept help from friends, neighbors and the parents of your children's friends.  Let them cook for you, handle the carpool and babysit when you need a break. Take a deep breath and know that you can come here for support (((HUGS)))
Posts.Title: TN with Starting chemo in Jan. -- 2 young children at home 11tyBillion CoolBreeze

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2010 10:35AM jenn3 wrote: Lottie - I have about 4 or 5 eyebrow hairs on each side and no eyelashes.  I've made the joke that I need to draw my face before leaving the house.  I  use a pencil and a brush that looks like a mascara brush for my eyebrows and I use black eyeliner around my eyes (not too thick).  Of course it doesn't look like the real thing, but it is what it is.  Most people didn't realize I don't have eyelashes until I tell them.  I think having glasses helps disguse it a little and I see that you're wearing glasses. Also, my right eye waters a lot - I don't rub the eye so I don't rub off the eyeliner, but I do dab it.  I also have back up in my purse if I need a touch up.   I say -   Show off your beautiful bald head and great makeup job - then you'll be free.......... Dawn - I'm sorry you're back under the wig. The hair will grow!!!  The hair on top of my head is thin and the scalp still shows, but I was just tired of covering my head.  I understand not being ready - it's a big step and we have to be ready emotionally.

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2010 07:14PM jenn3 wrote: AC was tough, no doubt and the worst were days 2-4 - like the flu, but worse.  There wasn't much I could do, but to listen to my body and rest.  I can say that hydration is very important and does help flush your system and help you to feel a little better.  I also found that no matter how bad I felt that by taking a walk if only around the block I felt better.  Some days I only made it to the corner, but it did help.  In the beginning I found it difficult to rest because I am a a person that likes to handle eveything myself and do something when I want it done.  However, I learned to let others help and just had to learn to rest..........  (((Hugs))) I know it seems terrible and like you'll never get through this, but you will.  And....will notice a pattern and be able to make plans around the good and bad days and good and bad times of the day.  It will get better.

I too had facial hair show up, which I didn't have before.  I was on a mini vacation with my sister, freaked out grabbed her razor and shaved it all off.  It hasn't grown back.  My underarm hair hasn't grown back, down under is coming back and my leg hair is growing like crazy.

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2011 08:17AM jenn3 wrote: Sharon - so glad to hear that you've moved to the 6 month appts - yipeeeeeee I have LE in my left arm, it seems to have slowly gotten worse over the last few months.  I asked my onc about the sleeve the last time I was there because it was really swollen and my shirts weren't fitting on that arm.  He said that it wasn't bad enough to require a sleeve - WHAT???  I was upset, but after speaking to him and looking into it - there are risks with the sleeve and I think what my onc was saying is not to wear the sleeve it I don't have to.  The swelling does seem to be getting a little better, but it's still swollen - no pain involved.  I do massage it when I remember, which is a few times a day.  The LE therapist I saw last year told me what to do and it does seem to work.  I rub from my chin downward to my chest with my entire hand - gently about 15 times, then the same on my arm between my elbow and shoulder, then between my wrist and elbow.  Starting at the top/neck clears the "roadway".  I repeat this motion two or three times each time I massage.  You don't have to rub hard, a gentle rubbing gets the lymphatic fluid moving.  Good luck.

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2010 07:51PM jenn3 wrote: Some days are just bad days..........the steroids from the chemo treatments cause bad days, dreary weather is always a downer and worse if your feeling down and sometimes just hearing or watching something related to what you're going through can trigger your emotions.  When those bad days happen and you recognize it, take a walk outdoors, watch a silly movie, call a friend, log onto youtube and watch a funny video - something to get your mind out of the funk.  If all else fails - chocolate always helps! arayofsunshine and katilaw - be easy on yourself - it is okay to have bad days, especially in the midst of treatment, your body is stuggling physically and emotionally.  I stayed home during treatment and in order to help me with my bad days I made sure that I woke up every day, took a walk, came home showered and got dressed (in comfy clothes).  Just that act of moving and routine helps give you something to look forward to everyday.  (((hugs))) I hope that you're feeling better by the time you read this.

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2011 11:50AM jenn3 wrote: I have two girls, 27 and 20 and I know that they are afraid of life without me.  My youngest seems to be the most open with me and has cried on my shoulders many times and we've had many long talks.  I'll tell you what I've told her because you're both close in age.  You are much stronger than you think you are.  You can and will get through this. There will be good and bad days. When you and your mom are having a good day - relish in it, enjoy every minute of it.  When a bad day comes along, work through it and know there will be good days to follow.  Like suggested above, you need to take daily walks and if you're feeling really stressed before you say something you wish you hadn't, take a walk.  Walking helps to release stress and gives you time to clear your head.  Eating good food does make a difference.  If you are already moody (like you said above) eating processed foods aren't the way to go.  Eat some fresh fruit and vegetables, drink some juice - stay away from the junk. Good luck (((hugs))) Jenn

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2010 08:42PM jenn3 wrote: Turk - my situation is a little different than yours, in that my DD wasn't pregnant when I was diagnosed, but boy did she lash out.  Her father passed away Apr 09, I was diagnosed Jun 09, surgery followed by chemo - she was wonderful, by my side, excellent in every way - all this happening (last year) during her Senior year of high school.  However, when I finished chemo at the end of Dec 09 things changed.  She started fighting with me, yelling at me and saying things that were so out of character.  Our home turned into a battle ground.  I was told by her counselor that in her mind I was doing better and now she could express her anger.  She was angry, angry that I got sick, angry that her dad passed away, angry that all of this happened in her senior year, angry that we couldn't tour colleges together.  In the end - we've worked through it all and she is back to my sweet, caring angel that she's always been. Maybe your daughter doesn't know how to react, she's emotional because her harmones are out of whack from the pregnancy, her Mom that she loves and is close to was just diagnosed with cancer - it may be too much to handle and she's keeping her distance to avoid the pain she's dealing with.  If you were close and had a good relationship, then she will come around. She just needs to figure out how to handle pregnancy, a new baby and a Mom with cancer.  She'll be there - just give her time.  In the meantime (((HUGS))) and know that we're here and we "get it".

I am from New Orleans and Katrina was a bitch to live through. I can remember the first time I came back to the city, we went to my friend's house to help her dig out anything that was salvagable..........We pulled up to her home and there were cars on roof tops, her garage was across the street, her gutters were in her hallway.  The silence was so loud, it screamed, no birds, no animals........It was horrible. I know that the we (people around the world) will be there to help, but I just can't imagine how the people of Japan are feeling right now.  Entire towns, homes, businesses have been wiped out.  I want to help and I know that I will donate time, items or something to organizations, but the magnitude of this is so big, I can't imagine how long and hard this will be for them to get through. Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2010 01:03PM jenn3 wrote: I soooooo get it.  Before going back to work I was more apprehensive about family/friend functions and seeing people I hadn't seen in a while.  I hated having to explain over and over and over...... how I was - "I'm fine", "yes, I had chemo", "no, they can't tell me if it's going to recur" and then the stories of family or friends they knew with cancer - almost always ending tragically.  HATED IT!!!  But........ I did learn that people reacted to the way I steered the conversation.  If I answered, "I'm fine", so tell me about your kids, pets, job, etc" - it directed the conversation away from me.   Then, if there was someone I wanted to talk to I talked.  And........ in all honesty if I was truly feeling bad or having pain issues, I skipped the event because I knew I wouldn't be good company.    Good luck with the decision and (((HUGS))) - it gets better.

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2010 07:58PM jenn3 wrote: I did DD AC, followed by weekly Taxol because of the trial I was in.  The DD AC is doable and like Kathy said the Neulasta is given to help your WBC.  Your onc will more than likely give you anti nausea meds with your chemo and will send you home with some as well.  We all handle the SE's differently, but the one common theme seems among everyone is to be sure to hydrate, drink plenty of water, before, during and after to flush your system.  Good luck and (((hugs)))

Posts.Title: It has spead to my brain...... jenn3 lwd

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2012 04:55AM jenn3 wrote: I am really feeling down, very down and wrote a long heartfelt message here yesterday to only have the damn computer blink and posting disappear.  UGH! I want to start with I am crying, terrified, panicky, sad and can't get my head out of my ass.  Everytime I start to laugh or do something not cancer related my mind goes right back to death.  I want to make sure everything is in order before it's my time, but we don't know when it's my time.  I can't relax and worry contstantly.  How do I transition?  What am I suppose to do, how do I relax and just enjoy life?  I get everything ready to die, then what?  It's seems if I'm not only preparing death, but now I'm watching everyone wait for me to die.  It's only a matter of time.  It's all so surreal. I know with triple negative breast cancer "it" moves fast when the end comes near.  But why when it hits the brain of the TNBC patient does it move so much faster than elsewhere?  Why wouldn't the radiation slow things up a little?  From what I've heard, gathered and read it seems once "it" comes to the brain it's about 3 months, 6 months if lucky and a year is the jackpot.  Why?  I really, really want to make it at least until June.  We can get through the wedding for DD1, have some good months to laugh with DH, family and friends, and DD2 will have finished up this semester at home.  Then there is the summer to "get used" to me being gone, family and friends still take the wedding cruise that is paid for to get away from all they've been through, then DD2 can go back to school in the fall.  Wouldn't it be nice if things fell so neatly into place? Between death, steroids, no sleep and radiation I am such a lost soul, feeling like I'm bumping from one room to the other - I HATE this!!!! I did call the doctor and spoke to his nurse a few minutes ago to ask about something to help calm me down.  Xanax maybe?  Jenn

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2012 12:50PM jenn3 wrote: Tomorrow is my last WBR and it's going well.  The funny thing is my face has gotten so puffy from the steroids that the mask has gotten really tight.  Today we had to really give it a push - it was quite funny.  Then of course when I'm done I have all of these lines all over my face from the mask.  But..........It's only a 2 minute treatment, no pain, discomfort or trouble so I can't complain.  Mentally I am starting to feel much better.  Physically I don't feel bad at all, so I told myself  "get yourself together and do what you were doing before the "episode".  There isn't any reason I can't cook, clean, run errands, shop, hobbies and of course prepare for the earlier wedding date.  I've kept busy for the last week, every single day and it's working.  When panick sets in a little medical intervention helps and I keep on going (unless I fall asleep). There are no words to express how much I appreciate all of your kindness, support and prayers.  It's nice to have my BCO family, one that gets it.  As wonderful as everyone around me is, they try to understand, but don't. (((Hugs))) Jenn

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2011 04:32PM jenn3 wrote: I am so sorry you are going through such a hard time. Men deal with things differently.  During my first round with this beast my DH acted like nothing was wrong, continued on with everything, rarely discussing the "beast".  He was supportive, helped around the house, ran errands, etc, but still didn't seem to "get it".   I know now that he was scared sh!%less and the best way for him to handle it was to ignore "it".   Men don't talk the way that women do and tend to bottle up their emotions.  Also, the caregivers, which are our spouses get overlooked a lot.........they and everyone else are so busy helping us that they get "forgotten".  My DH is terrified and if I were in his shoes I would feel the same.  Talk to your DH when there aren't any distractions, let him know you need him and let him feel it's okay to be sad, terrified and worried.  Encourage him to go have a drink with friends to talk about "it" or to have a night in which he can forget about "it".  If you're sitting on sofa together, hold his hand, touch his hair, let him feel you need him.  He'll come around, give him time.........Good luck and (((hugs)))

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2009 07:22AM jenn3 wrote: Weesa - poor Fetzer, but that is so funny................................ My mom was the pie maker growing up - one year my grandmother decided that she would take care of the pumpkin pie to "help" mom out.  My grandmother was so proud of herself, she had a great idea that saved everyone from baking - she bought a Mrs.Smith's frozen pie.  Which is fine, the pies aren't bad, but she didn't know they still had to be baked in the oven.  She had thawed the pie on the counter all day.................. and when she pulled it from the box, liquid pumpkin flew out across the table.  So there we stand with orange liquid across the kitchen table laughing hysterically as my grandmother who is determined not going to let Thanksgiving go by without pumpkin pie scoop all of the pumpkin liquid back into the shell with a spoon and then proceeded to bake it.  I don't remember how it tasted, but the memory (which we have in pictures) of grandmother scooping all of that liquid back into the shell is still funny.

Posts.Content: jenn3 wrote: This last week has been another rough week. I posted last week that I had been in the hospital again.  Several hours after that posting I had uncontrolled pain like I haven't felt in a long long time and was rushed to the hospital again.  I also still have unexplained fever spikes daily that lasts for a few hours before leaving.  The drs have run numerous test after test, after culture and are unable to find anything that would cause the fever.  One of the drs said that when the cancer is active it can cause fevers such as mine - UGH!!!  But..........they aren't sure so in addition to the IV antibiotics I am taking a prescription at home.  I was due for scan follow ups in 2 months, but due to the pain I had a CT scan and it looks like while on Gemzar/Carbo my cancer has taken off like weeds in summer.  It has moved into my ribs, thus the broken ribs and pain, the pluera, existing tumors are much larger and new tumors in the lungs. I am thankful that my body gave me signs to investigate this beast before another 2 months, but I am sad to know that I have progressed.  I will be starting Navelbine next week, pending the fever issue. I was really hoping for some more time before progression and am at a loss for words.  I hate breast cancer and hate that I have triple negative breast cancer!!! Jenn - June 2009 IDC-TN, Stage III, 02/2011 Stage IV mets to the lungs & spine / Laugh until your belly hurts, then laugh some more........... Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: The stable boy has left me :( jenn3 sincitydealer

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2009 11:36PM jenn3 wrote: I just did my second to last chemo today and was talking to the trial nurse about scans. She said like some of you said that first, we'll have to see if the insurance company will approve a scan. Second, the PET scan may not show anything, then in three months I may have symtoms and will need that PET scan and may run into trouble with the insurance company.  She said for the most part if you're not having symptoms, aches or pains the onc doesn't go looking for it.  It seemed to make sense while she was telling me what their procedure is. Of course she suggested I run this all by my onc when I see him again. He may have different plans because each case is different. I am triple negative, grade 3 and have started to worry more a lot more lately.  I know this is normal as we start to end treatment, but I do worry.  Prior to having found BC I two ER visits back to back (and it had been 25 yrs since I had been in the ER) with unexplained pain in the abdomen and the only thing they found were increased liver counts, for which they couldn't explain because I don't drink and hadn't been drinking and all of the tests and scans came up clear.  I've also had a lot of rib pain in the last year that my rheumatologist can't explain - so now I'm thinking "what if" it's mets that have been missed all this time?  Through all of this I've been fine, upbeat plans to grow old in and wrinkly, but now I am terrified.  I want the PET scan, but at the same time I don't.  Oh the mental games this disease plays with us.................

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2012 06:31AM - edited Jan 4, 2012 08:13AM by jenn3 When talking to my youngest DD#2 she said I shouldn't be so hard on the doctor that he is fighting and really does/did seem to have the best of intentions.  I left a message for the oncologist to discuss all that went on so that I can have a better understanding.  I also made a list of questions to ask in addition to the research I'm currently doing. Edited:  I spoke to the oncologist.  He said the reason for not having the gamma knife at this time is because the tumor we want to focus on is too big.  I asked if it was a possibilty down the road, he said it wasn't his field, but we could address it later with the neurosurgeon and/or radiologist oncologist.   I also asked him about stopping chemo for good and why was that decided.  It was as I thought, but couldn't get the family to understand.  He is stopping it for now, he has to while I am doing radiation.  We will discuss chemo again after WBR and the follow scans.  He is thinking maybe Halaven or Ixempra (spelling wrong??).   So for now, we will do WBR, follow up scans, possible chemo in Feb. and hope for as much quality time as possible.  DD#1 is going to move her wedding date to March possibly with just family, but keeping the bigger ceremony scheduled in July (I don't want her to cancel that).  My youngest rearranged her college schedule for this semester so that she is doing online courses, she has plenty of support from the school, her professors and the family and hopefully will get back to both online and classroom in the Fall.  DH and I are going to wrap up the final crap we have to with the financial stuff, insurances, funeral home, obits etc and go from there.  I just hope things move a little slower so I have some more time to get things in order before I have to just let it go.

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2010 08:14PM jenn3 wrote: I saw the spine dr today, which really didn't say much - he was okay.  In the end he agreed with what the primary is doing and asked that I let him know when the scan is done so that his office can be sure to look at it (they're all linked by a network).   So.... got now it seems to be the concensus that my AS is acting up and/or the medications I'm taking may no longer be working and the numerous bone spurs(arthritis) in my back is causing problems.  As for the pain, today wasn't a bad day.  I'm a little sore now, but not too bad.  Not sure if it's the new medicine or the "flare" up subsiding, but I'm not complaining. Thank all of you for your support and I will report back after my scan - which both dr's think will come out fine.

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2011 05:34AM jenn3 wrote: My onc won't give me chemo if I'm sick with a bacterial or viral infection.  I've only had it happen once, but that was enough for me to know I need to "be healthy" in order to get chemo.  You may be better calling the onc today to get antibiotics started today if you do have a bacterial infection so that it doesn't interfere with your chemo schedule.  I am so sorry you feel bad and hope that you feel better real soon.  Warm soup, tea w/honey, water, the bed and some good junk t.v. or a good book to read. (((HUGS)))Jenn

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2011 02:37PM jenn3 wrote: You are not alone in your feelings.  I have recently just stopped working.  Although the SE's from the Gemzar/Carbo don't seem to be has harsh as the AC, they are still not easy, especially week one when I have a lot of nausea.  Then I have the terrible fatigue from the Gemzar hitting the RBC hard and at times sleep more than I am awake and have had two blood transfusions in 3 weeks and may need another........... I also have collapsed vertabre in my thoracic spine and stenosis caused by the collasped vertabre, which was all from my spine mets. The pain is terrible, even with pain meds I have a hard time sitting or standing for any length of time.  I have some days that are wonderful and other days I just can't get out of bed.  I am fortunate that I don't have young children to raise while fighting this miserable disease.  And, am in awe of each and every one of you that have children to take care of - you are SUPERMOMS. (((HUGS))) Jenn

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2011 01:30PM jenn3 wrote: Creese/Lily - I was recently dx'd Stage IV too.  I am still learning to put one foot in front of the other.  I have done tons on research and it really does help when I'm talking to my onc.  I've researched trials, chemos and which one seem to work better with my TN status, I also reviewed pain management information on these boards on online so that I know all of my options besides just medication.  I had a wonderful day yesterday at my BIL's house, he and his wife had a big party for my nephew who just came back from Afganistan.  We were there from 1p - 11p, having the best time.  The only people that knew about my cancer were immediate family, my SIL's extended family didn't know, friends of theirs and friends of our nephew didn't know.  It was so nice to have an "almost" cancer free day.  This story is to let you know that although I'm still learning to cope, I am finding good days in the mix. (((hugs))) the women (and men) on these boards are amazing!

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2009 07:25AM jenn3 wrote: I had D boobs and they are completely gone now - everyone feels the need to look at my flat chest.......  I'm not wearing a wig - I've been using scarves and bandanas.  When I first started losing hair and went to a wig store to get a wig net to help hold the silk scarf on my head better the woman working there was really insistant on selling me a wig.  I repeatedly told her I wasn't interested, just needed the $2 net, she came up with every excuse in the book - then said the most insensitive thing, she told me that after the surgery I've been through and the hair loss I'd feel better about myself if I bought a wig.  Really??? Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2011 08:41AM jenn3 wrote: I am currently on Navelbine and find that within 2 - 3 days after getting chemo I start to feel pretty crappy, that lasts for another few days, then subsides to feel bad, which hangs around a bit longer, then it's time for chemo again.  If I have a week off, I get about 5 days in which I feel like my "old" self.   Prior to that I was on Gemzar/Carbo and had a similar cycle of feel bad days.  If I remember correctly that seemed to be my feel bad cycle for chemo back in 09 going through this the first time. Chemo sucks and there are some days I just don't want to even get out of bed, then there are the days that I feel good and I hit the floor running.  I try really hard to enjoy my good days to the fullest so that I don't feel so crappy (mentally) on my bad days. (((hugs))) I hope you feel better soon.

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2011 09:20AM jenn3 wrote: Ann - I know you don't want the port, but it really saves the veins.  As for risking a needle in the arm in which you had nodes removed, don't. I have mild lymphedema and hate it.  I can't wear certain dress shirts because the arm is swollen enough that it doesn't fit into a fitted shirt.  They can find veins in your other arm.  When I get my labs done they use a vein in my hand because they can't tie off my arm due to the port and they use the port for chemo (or for everything else when I was in the ER).   I've had two ports, the one in my chest and now the one on my inner arm.  The one on my inner arm really isn't noticable unless I show it to someone and it's high enough that a short sleeved (not super short) shirt covers it. I don't have experience with Navelbine, but have heard that it does stop traffic so you may want to stock up on prunes and laxatives. Jenn

Posts.Content: May 28, 2011 08:50AM jenn3 wrote: I know this is not what any of you want to hear, but my spine mets didn't show on the x-ray, it lit up on the PET and was confirmed by the MRI. I did have back pain, but what hurt me the most were my ribs, which we now know is the nerve.  It is radiating from the spine around my ribs.  Sharon - As cancer survivor we live in constant fear.  More than likely it's something else, arthritis, bulging disk, pulled muscles putting pressure on the nerves........ Jen had wonderful suggestions. Try to see if you can schedule a massage this weekend, drink plenty of water, try Aleve if you can take it and stretch.   However, if it gets worse, not better over the next week or so, have it checked out.  Your peace of mind is very important.  Jenn

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2010 08:30AM jenn3 wrote: Suze - I know you're scared.  I can remember sitting in the surgeon's office last year with my head spinning.  Within two weeks I had a mammo, biopsy and a bi-lat masectomy.  My dr's moved fast, so fast I didn't have time to think, which to this day I am thankful for.  I was dx'd with triple negative, stage III, grade III cancer and had 4/15 positive nodes.    At the time I really didn't know what any of it meant, but the women (and men) on these boards are invaluable, they have experience, knowledge and caring hearts.  The good thing is that your dr's are moving fast  - they are hitting this with all they have.  I am not going to say be positive, because I have learned to hate that statement, but I will say it is doable and you will be able to enjoy your children. (((hugs))) and know that we're all here for you whenever you need us.  Questions, ranting, sadness, frustration or just to ramble, we'll be here.

Posts.Content: jenn3 wrote: This last week has been another rough week. I posted last week that I had been in the hospital again.  Several hours after that posting I had uncontrolled pain like I haven't felt in a long long time and was rushed to the hospital again.  I also still have unexplained fever spikes daily that lasts for a few hours before leaving.  The drs have run numerous test after test, after culture and are unable to find anything that would cause the fever.  One of the drs said that when the cancer is active it can cause fevers such as mine - UGH!!!  But..........they aren't sure so in addition to the IV antibiotics I am taking a prescription at home.  I was due for scan follow ups in 2 months, but due to the pain I had a CT scan and it looks like while on Gemzar/Carbo my cancer has taken off like weeds in summer.  It has moved into my ribs, thus the broken ribs and pain, the pluera, existing tumors are much larger and new tumors in the lungs. I am thankful that my body gave me signs to investigate this beast before another 2 months, but I am sad to know that I have progressed.  I will be starting Navelbine next week, pending the fever issue. I was really hoping for some more time before progression and am at a loss for words.  I hate breast cancer and hate that I have triple negative breast cancer!!! Jenn - June 2009 IDC-TN, Stage III, 02/2011 Stage IV mets to the lungs & spine / Laugh until your belly hurts, then laugh some more........... Log in to post a reply

Denis - You may have already looked into this, but a lot of churches offer food give aways and our church also supplies the children with school supplies.   Trading is good.  I have a lot of paperback books because I like them better than my Kindle or hardcover books - I give them to my DD to sell at a used bookstore for credit so that she could get a book or books that she wants (escentially it was a trade).  My DH is in construction and there have been times that we trade work with friends.  My oldest daughter loves to bring her clothes to the consignment shop and trade her stuff for "new" stuff.  I also rent movies Red Box (not sure if you have them in Canada - $1/day) and sometimes the library because it's free.  I'm not sure if it's possible, but could you ask a friend to help organize a fund raiser.  Put together a picnic at a local park - maybe the friend could get some donated items that people could bid on and also a raffle. (((hugs))) I am so sorry that you have to worry about this during such a stressful time.....

Posts.Title: Why I Keep Going Fitztwins Member_of_the_Club

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2011 11:27AM - edited Mar 17, 2011 11:45AM by jenn3 I am so sorry you're struggling with money - good topic.  I handle all of the finances for our home and am worried about DH when it's his turn to take over....... Either buy clothes for your children on sale only, at consignment shops or thrift stores.  When I was a single parent I still liked buying a good pair of shoes that lasted longer, than inexpensive shoes - in the long run it was more bang for the buck, but I did buy them on sale only.  I also tried an experiement with myself after reading an article and decided see how long I could go without buying new clothes........I did pretty good and found clothes I hadn't used in a while that were like new - some with tags. Food, find dishes that go a long way.  Spaghetti and meatsauce, Beans w/rice (southern thing), casserole dishes.  Cheaper cuts of meat, chicken legs, wings and thighs.  Buying the whole chicken and roasting it or cutting it up for other uses.  I also like to buy the already cooked chicken using the breast meat for chicken salad sandwiches for lunch and the dark meat for gumbo or soup.  Edited:  I just thought of something - homemade pizza, my kids used to love to make homemade pizza, it was fun and cheap.  The store brand dough is something like .79, the sauce is a little more goes a long way and stores well in the fridge, then you can top it with anything you or your children like. We've cut back a lot by not eating out as often, going to the movies, but only the maitinee and finding free things to entertain with.  I also cleaned out our office and found a boat load of supplies that my daughter could use in school, binders, notebooks, loose paper, pens.  Stuff that had gotten pushed to the back of the closet and forgotten about.    Cable/Internet/Phone - search for a less expensive provider or cut back on services Good topic - thanks for starting.

Posts.Content: jenn3 wrote: For the last several weeks off and on throughout the day I've had trouble take deep breaths.  I'm not out of breath, I can walk around, up and down stairs, play with the dog, etc.  It's that feeling of oh I need a deep breath to stretch out the lungs and can't get it.  I find it hard and have to work at it a few times to get that deep breath.  It obvious to my daughter, who thinks I'm frustrated with her when I'm actually trying to get that deep breath.  At first I thought it was allergies, but I've been taking my allergy medicine faithfully as I have for the last 15+ years and I don't think it's allergies.  I've also suffered with allergy or exercise induced asthma so I tried my inhaler, but that didn't work either.  Has anyone had this feeling?  Wondering if radiation did something....... I do have my regular follow up appointment with my onc on the 13th and will discuss this, but I was just curious to know if any of you experienced this feeling of not being out of breath, but can't seem to get that deep breath that feels really good. Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2011 12:43PM jenn3 wrote: I am so glad that y'all get "it".   Thank all of you for the warm hugs, thoughts and suggestions. My mom is a wonderful caregiver, she seems to instinctively know what needs to be done without hovering, she is also a good note taker, listens wonderfully and will take down any nurse or doctor that gives her attitude, which can be funny because she is so sweet and softspoken that they don't expect it to happen.  Anywya, the onc doubled my long acting pain medication and asked that I keep track of how often I am using the percocet for breakthrough pain.  If the percocet doesn't help or I need double doses for relief he may change it too.  As of right now I've only taken 1 percocet (@7am) for break through pain, the pain is so much better.  The higher dose of morphine seems to have made a difference.  Maybe today I can get out for a good long walk with my dogs.  Even though it seems like an awful lot of medicine the onc assured me I am on very low doses.  Hmmmmm........  I started chemo (Xeloda) today, so far I'm feeling okay, but I'm sure just like last time, it's all cumulative and will catch up to me later.   So..........if I can keep from peeing and pooping on myself at work I'll be doing good.  Wouldn't that be embarrassingly funny? (((hugs))) to all of you!!!! Love, Jenn

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2010 08:43PM jenn3 wrote: Before I started rads, the thought of driving to the clinic every single day after a full day of work did not seem appealing and I really wasn't looking forward to it.  However, it became part of my daily routine and like the others said I spent more time undressing and dressing than I did on the table.  I also had the same techs everytime I went and they were always in a good mood and helped make the experience more tolerable.  I seemed to breeze right through.  I did have some skin issues and discomfort after it was over, which caught me off guard, but it's all doable and I am glad to say I am recently finished.  The start of radiation, like chemo seems like it will take forever and going daily just seems like it's such a burden, but the time will fly by and before you know it you'll be writing back on this thread or start another thread to say you are done, done, done.

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2010 03:11AM jenn3 wrote: I'm back at work full time and while I feel like I'm doing pretty good, but do find certain situations or procedures that slip my mind and I am forced to look up the information.  Concentration is better, but it still seems a little off at times.  I do try to mentally challenge myself with crosswords and other mind games - working out the muscle between the ears............. Even though we have computers, phones and other electronic equipment to give us reminders I find that the good ole' post-it notes help the best.  I use a bright color and stick it to my phone or my keys if I want to remember something as I'm walking out of the door, on the dash of the car or on the phone receiver at work.  I have to say I needed these before chemo - so I can't blame it on chemo brain.  I also leave messages for myself on my voicemail at work - this really helps a lot.

Posts.Title: MORE Progression........... jenn3 AnacortesGirl

Posts.Content: jenn3 wrote: I just started taking Xeloda last week.  My onc wanted to do another set of scans, he said that it had been 4 weeks since my last set of scans and he wanted a new baseline.  In those 4 weeks the tumors in my lungs have grown.......2 tumors grew 4x their size, the other one doubled in size and there are many more numerous tumors in my lungs.  My onc said that I should start on "doublets" of chemo, he feels single agent isn't the way to go because of the aggressiveness of the cancer.  We talked about various chemo regimes, including the Xeloda combined with something else.  We decided on Gemzar/Carboplatin, which he wants to start right away - Monday or Tuesday.  My platelets are a little low and he said that the Gemzar hits the platelets hard, so I will go in tomorrow, Thurs and Fri for injections to help build the platelets and somewhere between tomorrow and sometime next week have my port put back in.  DH and I talked and have decided that it's time for me to call it quits with work.  This new round of chemo will hit me hard and it makes no sense on dragging myself into work when I feel rotten.      We talked and think it's in my best interest mentally and eventually physically to stop working and focus on my health.  I can't stop crying - I can't imagine not working.  I know my health is more important and the logical side of me says that being able to stay home and enjoy my time with family and friends is more important than going to work.  But..........I do love my job, co-workers and clients.  I've always worked and been at this job for over 15 years.  I am afraid to make that final step, no I'm terrified I knew I'd have to move on to other chemos, but didn't expect it to happen so fast. I had finally reached a much more peaceful place and have just been so happy.  I guess I was so far out on the boat of D-nile having so much fun, I didn't see the big rogue wave coming........... On the upside, my gardens are looking great.  I also decided to try vegetables this year and so far the plants are looking good (tomato and bell peppers).  Jenn - June 2009 IDC-TN, Stage III, 02/2011 Stage IV mets to the lungs & spine / Laugh until your belly hurts, then laugh some more........... After eating the beets my DD brought home my urine turned reddish, after it did that through the night and into the next day I knew I had something else wrong and called the onc.  Luckily I remembered the beets soon after leaving the message, called and cancelled the frantic message.  Apple - my DH feels exactly like you do when it comes to beets. :) I had a wonderful day today my my youngest DD, we shopped, went to lunch and just talked.  It was a wonderful day.  A much needed day.  And.........it let me know that being home will be the best thing for me.  I'd much rather have days like today without worrying about trying to get back to work. Dream-I laughed at your DeNile with work, because I did something along those lines during my first round with chemo.  I had surgery, then started chemo and after 2 months of telling my boss, next week - he finally told me to quit trying to come in and stay home until I finished chemo.  And...to appease me, set me up online at home.  I really didn't do much, but it made me feel a little better. KK - I think I'll take up your idea and get dressed up, visit a nice restaurant in the middle of the day - what fun.
Posts.Title: MORE Progression........... jenn3 AnacortesGirl

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2012 02:23AM jenn3 wrote: I don't know how I missed this, but I did. I found BCO in 2009 after my initial diagnosis.  Like all of us, when I was dx'd I jumped on the computer to do some research.  Found BCO and I think must of read the articles for hours on end.  I read Komen and other sites, but found BCO user friendly.  I then discovered the discussion boards, something I had never done (share personal info) or would have never done, but these boards have been an emotional lifesaver. I was dx'd June 19, 2009 with breast cancer, within two weeks I had a bi-lat masectomy, discovered it was triple negative and enrolled in a trial.  The trial was a combo of drugs I would have taken, but adding Avastin.  I ended up in the arm without the Avastin and was disappointed, but it is what it is. I did chemo from Aug - Dec of 09, rads in Feb/March (34 sessions) and was then NED.  I spent the rest of 2010 NED.  I had that feeling that something wasn't right, but I'll be honest I couldn't say what it was just that feeling.  I suffer with arthritis and other back issues so it was hard to know one pain from the other.  However, my onc wanted to appease me and ordered the x-ray, which let to the CT, which let to the MRI, which let to stage IV diagnosis.  I did a course of radiation on my spine for pain mgmt and started chemo.  I was on chemo until Dec 28th 2011 when the brain mets were discovered and just finished WBR.  I meet with the onc this week to discuss follow up scans and more chemo (I hope).  I then have a follow up visit with the rad onc the following week hoping the big tumor in the cerebrel part of the brain shrunk enough for the gamma knife or some sort of a targeted procedure.  I am not ready to give up, a little more time. Whew............I didn't realize I remember so much.

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2011 08:13PM jenn3 wrote: You will find that a BMX is not a terribly painful surgery.  Unfortunately I've had 4 or 5 different surgeries and the BMX was one of the least painful surgeries.  Yes, you will be sore and there will be discomfort, but pain medication, warm showers and the exercises you will be given will all help.  You should only have difficult movement in the upward positions and if you do what your told you should be fine. As for the drains.  I hooked them to my shirts with large safety pins and when I took a shower I hooked them to a large 1 1/2 in ribbon around my neck.  I did find that button up pj's were easier the first week to get in and out of and slept with a body pillow so that I didn't roll over or DH didn't bump me.   Good luck.

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2012 02:08PM jenn3 wrote: I am TN and just dx'd 12/28 with brain mets among others, I knew back in Nov / Dec something was amiss, but kept talking myself down saying the usual.  It's stress.  I was always a headache suffer and when I started chemo inJune 2009 they stopped, that is until now.  Back in Nov-Dec I noticed that my eyes were "playing"  tricks on me, fast movements caused me get slightly off balance and my appetite changed from getting nauseated to fine the next.  Like the rest of us, I played denial, denial, denial, it didn't work all that it helped with was to remind me that the outcome would be the same, only by 30-60 days.  I found the s/e's from both the radiation and Navelbine to be rough, both in different ways, not easy.  Don't blame you, take care of you and come here to vent. Good luck (((hugs))) Jenn
Posts.Title: Venting--more mets?? formygirls ibcmets

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2011 07:11PM jenn3 wrote: I am new to all of this and had no prior experience, except the vague memories of my best friend's Mom passing from cancer when we were young.  I have just been recently dx'd with mets to the lungs and spine - I am sad, very sad, but I want to live as long as I can for not only myself, but my family friends and my very best/closet friend mentioned above.  I want to say those things that need to be said, put things in order to the best of my ability, love them for as long as I can and make as many happy memories as I can with whatever time I have left.  It could be that your friend can't see past her depression right now, like the others have said maybe she needs depression medicaiton to help her see things more clearly.  If not medication, maybe a talk with someone neutral to the situation.  Like the others have mentioned, a masectomy at this point doesn't seem to be the right thing to do.  I really think another opinion is in order.  It sounds like you really care for your friend and I wish you luck in helping her.

Posts.Content: jenn3 wrote: It seems the reality of what I'm dealing with is really starting to hit. I find myself crying at the drop of a hat, tearing up everytime I talk about "it" and feel like the world is spinning around me while I'm standing still.  And.........the pain is just unrelenting, which isn't helping.   The portion of the spine that was so painful is much better, but the pain in my ribs, muscle spasms and upper spine is horrible.  I've been trying to "handle" it by taking my pain meds every 3 - 5 hours, working, radiation, home, bills and family obligations.  Last night was the icing on the cake - I had a huge meltdown.  Because, that wasn't enough my DD, who is away in school called because she was having a severe migraine, with deafness and numbness on her left side.  She ended up in the ER with a slew of test because she does have a rare neurological disease and they needed to be sure it wasn't a flare up - "luckily" it was a migraine. I went into the office today, talked to my boss and co-workers and am taking off a few days to a week, to do nothing, something or nothing again. I also made a phone call to my onc and let him know I just can't handle the pain - I need more help. He was so nice on the phone, understanding and made me feel better.  He gave me 12 hour medicine to take and said to continue what I'm taking for breakthrough pain.  I am terrified of the long acting medicine, but I just took it.  I already feel better mentally knowing I have some time off from work with no plans.  I can just relax. Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2011 05:03AM - edited Mar 11, 2011 05:03AM by jenn3 Cindy, well said about the relationship with the doctor.  Like you I didn't need hugs and comfort from my oncologist, I wanted someone to tell me like it is..........and that understands my whacky sense of humor.  Luckily I found that on the first try. Shannon - the doctor relationship is very important.  Also, like the others said, ask questions, what type of breast cancer? What stage, What grade? Node involvelment? If so, how many? Surgery?  If so, what is he recommending and what about recon? Chemo? What kind of chemo? radiation?  Having your Aunt with you is very important, because you don't hear everything, your mind is racing and trying to absorb as much as possible.  Good luck and let us know how the appt went (((Hugs)))
