Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2011 11:56PM jenn3 wrote: I've been very vigilant since my DD received the wrong dosage of sedation medication before a surgery.  Thank goodness the doctor had verbally told me what to give her before the procedure because the pharmacy (Walgreens) had given instructions to give my DD triple the dosage.  I raised hell, they apologized, etc.....  I stopped using Walgreens for years, but they opened a new store near my home and its "easy". Another thing to watch for.  My DH had an ER trip for a cut on his hand, when he got to the pharmacy to fill the prescription of antibiotics they realized that the ER gave him someone else's prescription.  An error by the ER, he had to go back to exchange prescriptions.  Wow!!!! It's better to be safe and get the names of the medications being prescribed, the dosages and amounts given and then match that up to what is filled at the pharmacy.  Mistakes happen.
Posts.Title: Check your prescriptions Kimmom jenn3

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2011 02:30PM jenn3 wrote: Here I go again...........The pain meds that I was given don't seem to be working as well, only a week or so later.  I am having another meltdown.  I called the onc, his office called back and I just started crying, I don't even know who I talked to - it wasn't his nurse, but I was so upset I didn't even catch the name (she gave it when she called).  My back and ribs hurt and lucky me, I keep pissing on myself in drips and drabs without feeling it come out.  I notice at night I wake up damp between my legs, thank god not on my bed and when I go to the bathroom it just falls out when I stand up - disgusting!!!!  Whomever I spoke to is going to talk to my dr and call me back, they may have me come do some blood work, urine test and change my meds again.  I am so not used to this role of feeling helpless.........I am normally the "strong one" who cares for and comforts everyone else, but it's hard to be strong when the pain is overwhelming me.  I hate this role of not being able to do what I want!!!  It sucks!!! And..... I am terrified that I am taking too many meds, although the oncs office said it seems to be a low dose........ I'll see what happens when they call back. I'm rambling, needed to vent........thanks for listing (AGAIN).
Posts.Title: ANOTHER Meltdown.... jenn3 MCTHO

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2011 09:35AM jenn3 wrote: I woke up this morning in so much pain I thought, not again.  I called into work and told them I couldn't make it in.  However, after bathing and moving around, along with pain meds it does seem that the pain has lessened for now.  The onc called back this morning @ 7am, apologizing because the intern I spoke to had just given him the message.  I am going in to see him this afternoon.  He wants to talk about tweaking my medications and about the leaking urine issue.  DH thinks what may have contributed to such another bad bout is that I overdid it this weekend because I was feeling better, in addition to driving 5 hours both ways Sat & Sun to see my daughter.  I think he may be right.  When I feel good I need to remember that I still have issues and not overdo it.  But.........it was French Quarter Festival weekend and my DD needed Mom. When I feel good I forget the consequences of overdoing it.  Maybe I'll remember this time. I can't take Ibuprofen because I am on Indomethacin for my Anklosing Spondolysis (AS) - However, I'll ask my primary again just to be sure if I can mix the two. Susan - My friend and I split the best tasting roastbeef poboy from Boucherie, they had a tent at the festival.  The roast beef was almost creamy it was so tender.  Yum!!!

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2010 08:08PM jenn3 wrote: Growing up my Mom was (still is) a wonderful source of knowledge and would talk to us about the different religions. I feel like I've jumped back in time and am listening to the words of my Mom all over again.  I guess she wanted us to understand as much as we could about all religions, not just what we were. We do celebrate Christmas.  Our home is decorated, we put up a tree, I watch cheesy holiday movies, I shop (but not like a wild woman), I love to bake, I love to share the baked foods and gifts with friends, family and neighbors, I love to wrap and I absolutely love to see the awe in the eyes of children when they see what has been left by Santa.  To put it in a nutshell, I love the magic of the season.  Yes, it is commercialized, yes, there are people that go waaaay overboard and spend money they don't have and yes, there are many people who don't realize that or take into account what the celebration is about.  But...in the end, it brings families together and yes these same families do pray together, go to church together and are reminded what the holidays are about.  Happy Christmas Happy Hanukkah Happy Holidays

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2011 09:00PM jenn3 wrote: I'm crying as I read your responses.........thank you so very much.  After posting this, I called my mom in complete meltdown mode.  She of course was here in less than 15 minutes, her fastest time yet.  I laid down on the sofa with my mom rubbing my head and shoulders (I call it petting).  I fell asleep and woke up a few hours later feeling much better.  DH came home, upset because I hadn't called him, but he was at work and I didn't want to disturb him.  I woke up feeling better, but it seems the pain is coming back and I'll need to go lay down again.  I am just tired of feeling bad and have never felt so vunerable.  Nerida - I think you hit the nail on the head. I guess I am afraid.  I am entering into a world in which I don't want to be in.  I want to continue being the mom, wife, friend, daughter, sister, cousin, godmother that I was prior to BC.  I want to have a good time without the shit looming over me like a dark cloud.  I don't want to be the "patient".    I was getting ready to delete this because it's so negative and a downer, but decided not to, it's what I feel at this moment.  However, I do want everyone to know that I am usually the one who can laugh in the darkest of times.  I know my mental attitude will get better and I'll laugh again. Oh..........the life of a cancer patient - isn't it exciting?

I got home from work, finished cooking the dinner I started in the crockpot, watered all of my plants that need some TLC because they're new, filled the bird feeders, cleaned the birth baths and made it for a 2 mile walk with one of my dogs (the youngest).  DH is worried I may have over done it and will feel it tomorrow, but it feels good to have minimal pain and have the energy to do something other than nothing. I am supposed to have more scans sometime in the next week (still waiting to hear from the nurse).  The onc wants new baseline scans now that I'm starting chemo and wants to get a look at the liver.  I should have more answers by next week, more tumors, the same, what they saw on the liver last time, etc. Again, I cannot express my gratitude to all of you for your continued kindness during my meltdowns.  BCO Sisters are the best!

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2011 01:41AM jenn3 wrote: I love knowing there is a place to come and that my BCO Sisters and Brother (Yan) "get it".  I talked to my boss today and tried to be professional, but the tears were coming whether or not I wanted them.   Then we we talked about posting my position out, the tears really came rolling down my cheeks.  We decided that we wouldn't say anything today, but make an announcement next week to the group.  After that we'll begin the process of finding someone to fill the position, train and I'll be on my way.  I know it's the best thing for me, but knowing I won't be going back is painful.  I had planned on taking some time off from work starting tomorrow through Tues/Wed because my youngest daughter is home from college on Spring break, so the timing of all of this seems to have worked out.  Thank you for the information on Carbo/Gemzar. Being TN is scary and it seems that so many people I talk to just don't understand that chemo is the ONLY option.   We decided on this combination in part because of what I've read on these boards.  It really helps talking to the onc understanding some of what he is telling me.  Today, tomorrow and Friday I will have Neupogen injections. Monday I start chemo and Tuesday I will have outpatient surgery to get the port. I have to say, the Neupogen shot hurts.  The nurse offered it to me in my belly or arm.  I was in my work clothes and didn't feel like having to get partially undressed so I said, the arm is fine. Holy Crap that shot stings........and that is what I said quite loudly.  As she's pushing the drug, she says "it MAY sting a little", just about the same time I said CRAP THIS HURTS.  After realizing how loud I was I felt like I had to apologize to the people in the chairs getting some sort of medication or hydration by IV.  And.......we all had a good laugh.  I'll get it in the belly tomorrow. Oh....and thanks for the info on the blueberry plant.  I'll let my DD know that her one plant is lonely and needs a friend in order to make blueberries.

Posts.Content: jenn3 wrote: With Thanksgiving coming up this week I thought we could share some stores, traditions, foods we eat and whatever else comes to mind...................... I normally host Thanksgiving each year and have decided I will do it again this year........... The first few years of hosting such a big event are learning years - My first time hosting Thanksgiving I was really worried because I had never cooked a turkey and had no idea what I was doing- my grandmother had always done it.  So.......... I listened to different people got ideas and made my first turkey.  It was wonderful! Tender, juicy and full of flavor.  Everyone raved over my turkey - I was so proud of myself.  Year two rolls around I knew I had it made............ I could make a turkey!!!  I was ready.  I woke up early to get the turkey ready, stuffed it and put it in the oven.  I was so organized I had everything ready, house decorated, cleaned and side dishes prepared.  Everyone started showing up with more yummy dishes - the wonderful aroma of Thanksgiving was everywhere, including the turkey.  It was time........ the turkey was ready to come out of the oven.  We took the turkey out of the oven, put it on the platter sliced into it......................and it was raw in the middle.  Apparently the damn turkey must have still been a little frozen in the middle, then I stuffed it and underestimated the cooking time.   Year 2 - we ate Thanksgiving without a turkey  - it went home as left overs. Jenn - June 2009 IDC-TN, Stage III, 02/2011 Stage IV mets to the lungs & spine / Laugh until your belly hurts, then laugh some more........... Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: jenn3 wrote: I have suffered with back pain for years (bulging disks, spurs/arthritis and anul fissures) so it's not uncommon for me to have back pain.  I recently had a Facet Joint Injection (have been getting them for about 7 years) and it helped a little in one area.  However, the pain has gotten really, really bad.  There is an area in the middle of my back that throbs, my ribs hurt so bad, but not nearly as bad as my right hip bone and my neck is killing me.  I cannot get pain relief with medication, heating pads, hot soaks nothing helps. It was so bad two nights ago I actually thought about the ER. I had a follow up with the surgeon that handled my achilles tear and he suggested and made an appt with a spine specialist, which is this week and I do have an appt with my primary this week too.  My DH, children, friends and family know that I have back pain, but I'm doing everything I can to hide it.  DH just thinks its the normal pain - he doesn't know how bad it is.  I know I should be able to talk to my DH, family or friends about my worries, but I can't.  I am more worried about their reactions to something I don't know yet.  I am just so tired of being the "sick one".  I don't want to be the patient.  But...........I am worried.  Why is the pain so bad?  What if?  I don't usually worry like this - I really don't and I never worry about the "what if's" in life and just wrote that in a letter to my DD who left home for her 1st year of college this weekend.  Worrying about the "what if's" is a waste of good energy, but here I am stuck in the "what if's" - this is new territory for me. I know that I should feel comfortable enough to talk to someone, but I don't.  I have always been the caregiver personality and am the caregiver for many people and the thought of worrying anyone after what they've gone through with me in the last year is just too much of a burden to give them right now.  I don't have answers - not yet.  This could simple be a more advanced stage of the type of arthritis (anklosing spondylosis) I have or I may have injured something more than I thought. So....I am writing this to my cyber friends so that I can get this off of my chest and know that all you can understand these crazy feelings. Jenn - June 2009 IDC-TN, Stage III, 02/2011 Stage IV mets to the lungs & spine / Laugh until your belly hurts, then laugh some more........... Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2010 07:09PM jenn3 wrote: Diana - I am sorry your are suffering and worried (((HUGS))).  Last week my onc gave me the you're in remission speach, then said that it's going to be natural for me to think that every ache and pain is cancer related and it's his job to reassure me I'm fine or if he feels it's been lingering too long to run some test.  He also said to tell him everything even if it seems minor, if it lingers for 2 or more weeks he wants to know so that he can determine whether or not it requires more testing.  So.....it's natural to worry and the more pain you have the more you worry, but make sure you tell your onc everything.  The drugs we've taken to fight this beast tears up our bodies in so many ways or it could be an injury or inflammation of some sort.  Good luck and I hope you feel better.  (((MORE HUGS))))

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2011 07:38AM jenn3 wrote: Jenn - My curls came in thick, thick, thick and spirals.  I went to a hairdresser that specializing in curly hair.  Curly hair should not be cut like straight hair, nor should you comb or brush it unless you're in the shower with conditioner.  Curly hair is much dryer than straight hair, so be sure to use the right products.  I am using Deva, which is a line specifically for curly hair and I love my curls.  Shampoo that foams will dry your hair out, use a product that doesn't foam.  I love my curls.  I also use another product in the Deva line that you put on after you get out of the shower, it is meant to hold the curls and keep them soft and managable.  Myhairdresser also said that she prefers to work with the hair's natural tendencies rather than fight it.  Meaning she would prefer I don't try to keep it straight.  That way you have less bad hair days........ Good luck and look for products and a sytlist that specializes in curly hair, it will make all of the difference in how you handle your hair and in loving your hair.

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2010 11:37AM jenn3 wrote: I read from so many women that Taxol was a breeze and was truly caught off guard with the pain that I suffered with from Taxol.  There were days that just having my clothes touch my body hurt and worse yet if someone tried to hug me I was in tears.  In addition to these crazy pains that shot through my thigh, neuropathy and a few other problems.  I ended up with strong pain medication every four hours starting on day 2-3 after treatment for about 2-3 days, then it would taper off until the next treatment.  I hated it, but it was the only thing that helped.  Also I had pain during my Taxol infusion, but my onc said he had never heard of pain during an infusion, but it happened during all 12 infusions, of course I didn't realize it was from the Taxol until infusion 4.  But....I figured it out, took medication before the infusion and was fine until day 2 or 3 when the crazy pains I mentioned earlier started up.  I thought it was me being nuts, but after talking to the onc nurses they said they had other patients with the same problems.  I hope you get pain relief soon, don't be afraid of medication - you'll be fine as long as you are taking it for what it's intended for.  (((HUGS))) It gets better.
Posts.Title: Taxol Pain mmcmahan jenn3

Posts.Content: jenn3 wrote: Over the last month I've had so many test to confirm my mets and add'l test due to an error by the MRI techs that I can't count them on one hand.  The last "correction" MRI picked up some trouble in my liver.  However, my onc really can't run another test because I've had so many and at this time he feels it's not a good idea to give me contrast AGAIN - I will be rescanned in a few weeks anyway.  But......he did tell me IF I wanted another test he would do something else, but because I couldn't have contrast it would more than likely still be inconclusive.  I agreed to wait because we are starting treatment and when I was rescanned we would look at it again.  Today I visited with my onc to get my first Xgeva shot and a check in to see if the radiation is helping with the pain and talk about starting my first round with Xeloda.  We looked at my blood work and my liver counts are extremely high.  And........I rechecked my MRI report and it showed a possible mild blockage of the bile duct.  It's looking like the liver may be involved.  I thought I'd have more time before it headed to the liver, my mets just showed up in my lungs and spine.........now only three weeks after that the liver?  This means that the cancer is on the move and I am terrified.  I want more time with my family, with my friends and with my dogs.  All I could think about today was, should I quit work now and spend my precious time left with my family?  However, if I do that too soon in this miserable journey then money may become an issue?  How will I know when it's time?  I've already talked to my HR Dept and understand how and what will need to be done (upside is the benefits are better than I thought).   I know these decisions are decisions only I can make based on my finances and discussions with my doctor, but I'm worried and I want more time! Jenn - June 2009 IDC-TN, Stage III, 02/2011 Stage IV mets to the lungs & spine / Laugh until your belly hurts, then laugh some more........... Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2011 10:45AM jenn3 wrote: Thanks for the support.  Yesterday was such a crappy day for me. I couldn't see past my own sadness and despair.  I can't remember the last time I felt so low and alone, surrounded by love and support.  My DH walked in the door to me sitting in the chair crying.........hoping to get me up and moving, he asked if we were still going shopping.  I need something to wear to a shower because my lymphedema arm is so swollen most of my clothes are too tight on the arm.  I said "NO- I want to just sit and cry", but came to my senses, cleaned up and went out.  It helped my mood, then a few hours later I started feeling sorry for myself again.  I woke up this morning feeling much better, emotionally and have a busy weekend planned - it should keep my mind busy.    I have excellent health insurance coverage and my payout for co-pays and deductibles is very little.  I have 6 months STD, indefinite LTD, with my health insurance coverage ending after 2 years on LTD.  My HR dept did tell me that we do have accelerated benefits, I'm not sure about terminal illness payout, but will check with that today.

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2011 09:53PM jenn3 wrote: The first port I had was done during my BMX.  When it came out the surgeon didn't give me any happy juice, but simply numbed the area really good and out it came, very minimal discomfort.  I really expected something along the same lines for this, although it was going in not out.    It was a pretty bad ordeal and I can't believe it happened.   If I had been a bitchy, whiney, complaining patient, m-a-y-b-e .....I could have thought well they don't believe me.  But, I wasn't - the nurse even made the comment that I didn't seem to want to bother anyone when I asked for some "chapstick" IF they had time while I waited 4 hours.  Other than that, I didn't call or ask for anything.  I really understand that things happen and not everything will be on time, etc......  Also, my pain issues had really gotten much better too.  I felt great after chemo with the exception of being tired from a long day.  The next day wasn't too bad either, that is until the port was put in. I will write a letter, but want to do it with a level head and make sure that I write the letter when I'm not hopped up on drugs and then reread it before putting it in the mail. I also want to talk to my onc about it on Tuesday when I meet with him.  I still can't believe that it happened.

Posts.Content: jenn3 wrote: I really haven't shared much about my youngest daughter and some of our tough times here, but she just called with an award she received that is such an honor I have to share how she got to it.  Two years ago she was a healthy normal teenager (sophmore), then after a cheerleading performance the first week of school she starting having pain in her foot.  We thought she had sprained her ankle and treated it as such, it didn't get better went to the doctor they took x-rays and various test, didn't see anything and suggested a boot.  Again, got worse - more testing, nothing..... Then this mysterious pain and inability to move her foot went to both feet - she was suddenly in a wheelchair - a month later it was in her hands and she was unable to even bathe or brush her own teeth.  Again...... doctors don't know what it is.  She pushes through - still attending school, her friends helping her with her work, teachers giving oral test instead of written.  She works hard in therapy and manages to get out of the wheelchair, but still struggles with pain. One year later she is diagnosed with a rare neurological disease that is treatable.  She hobbles through the next year trying different medications, learning to manage the disease, but is unable to cheer anymore, which disappoints her, but you do what you have to in life.  During this time, she continues to volunteer at the Lighthouse for the Blind, continues to do various other volunteer work with Key Club and maintains honor roll status.  Then......... the fall of last year her dad passes away and early summer I'm diagnosed with Stage III Breast Cancer. The start of her Senior year she has to deal with the death of a parent and the cancer diagnosis of another in addition to Senior year stress.  Does she give up?  Nope, she works just as hard with her volunteer work, helps more around the house and manages to get her grades up even higher!!!  And.............her hard work has started to pay off with scholarships she's being offered to various colleges, but that's not all............ She was nominated by her peers for Louisiana Young Heros Award - an award given literally to only handful of kids each year.  The committee interviewed her teachers and school administrators, talked to various other people she's worked with and she has WON the award.  My sweet angel will be one of a few select kids in the State to receive this award and will be honored with a luncheon at the Govenor's Mansion in April (by which time I hope to have more hair).  I am so proud of her............. She has overcome so much in the last few years and has ended up on top!!!!  Amazing what our kids can do when they put their minds to it.  I am so proud of her and just wanted to share it with my BC Sisters. Jenn - June 2009 IDC-TN, Stage III, 02/2011 Stage IV mets to the lungs & spine / Laugh until your belly hurts, then laugh some more........... Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Proud Mama!!! jenn3 NancyD

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2010 04:23PM jenn3 wrote: I am just returning after being out for 6 months.  I too had worked my entire life and didn't know what to do with myself and daytime television is terrible.  I had the same treatment you did, but in reverse order.  I did the AC first, then Taxol.  I woke up at the same time every morning throughout chemo to keep somewhat of a routine.  I got up early, walked, came home had breakfast and a shower then if it was a good day I would do various things that needed to get done, errands, housecleaning, etc and/or visit with friends, movies, lunch and my hobby garden.  I've always been the cook in the house, but I also started searching for new recipes and tried different things with the family.  Unfortunately for me SE's were not kind to me during treatment and I had to learn that on my bad days it was okay to rest and not feel guilty.  I'm a very high strung, can't sit still, OCD person and resting during the day was hard mentally.  But...... there did come a point when I had to tell myself it was okay to sit still, rest and not feel compelled to clean or have everything "just right".  And............ in the end going back to work after so much time off hasn't been bad.  I've had a huge amount of support and the strangest thing is I've just rolled right back where I left off and don't feel out of place. Enjoy the time off - rest when you need to w/o guilt and use the rest of the time to what you want at your own pace.

Posts.Title: Tough few days - OUCH! jenn3 stephanief

Posts.Content: jenn3 wrote: Monday, I had my first chemo of gemzar/carbo.  I had to do the chemo though the vein because my port surgery wasn't scheduled until the next day.  That's fine, I'll have it for the next round.  Whew......that Gemzar stung, but nothing that wasn't helped with a warm pack while it was going in.   It was a long day, with labs, onc and chemo.  Came home, felt pretty good, watched television went to bed.  Woke up the next morning feeling a bit uneasy, but not queasy or nauseated.  However, my port surgery was scheduled so I couldn't eat or drink anything.  Sprite would have worked wonders.  Then the hospital calls and tells me they have a brain aneurysm surgery scheduled before me that may run late, delay coming in by an hour.  I got there and still had to wait another 4 hours before my surgery began.  It's all good, I'm still not complaining or upset, I get it.  I went through all of my current medications with the nurse and then told her of my concerns with the "happy" drugs because of the medication I'm taking.  She assured me it was't a problem.   WELL..........GUESS WHAT????? Something went terribly wrong!!!  As they were hooking me up, prepping my arm I turned my head sideways and closed my eyes going into relax mode.  They shot me with some numbing medication, which is when I opened my eyes and let them know I was in pain and still wide awake.  The nurse then tells the radiologist doing the procedure, I thought she was asleep, I gave her Versaid.  I said nope, I'm not asleep IT'S HURTING, they gave me the rest of the Fentenyl and by now I am hysterical and can feel EVERYTHING.  I can feel the coil going up the vein, hear the sounds, feel the tugging, etc.........I was hysterical, but the didn't stop.  They claimed to have even given me another vial of Fentenyl.    Something didn't work.  I was straight as an arrow by the time they rolled me into recovery.  So much so, I walked out 10 minutes later with my instructions in hand.   I woke up the next morning in so much pain, muscles spasms, stiffness and overall pain I went hysterical again.  And...........I was running 102 fever.  I took a double dose of pain meds, went into the hospital and had to have cultures done of the port area, blood work and blood cultures, plus my neupogen shot.  Holy Moly Guacamole...... I couldn't speak without crying I was in so much pain.  My youngest DD said it was the first time she'd ever seen me like that - I'd have to agree. From that point to my family kept me on a strict every 4 hour pain medication regime so that it wouldn't get out of control again (even in the wee hours of the morning).   Honestly, I think for whatever reason, I didn't get the drugs via IV, there must have been a blockage.  Then, I was in so much pain that my entire body tensed up so much while my arm was strapped to the table that a nerve was pinched in my neck and shoulder, of course terrible back spasms and because the pain was off the wall my nerves were pissed and everything hurt.    Slowly, I am feeling better, but I will never EVER go through that again if I can help it.  The hospital director will be getting a letter and maybe a phone call on this one, in addition to another problem I had.  I just can't believe a facility this big with so many accolades let me go through such a barbaric procedure. Can you imagine, having nothing for pain other than one freakin' local numbing shot while having a port inserted into your bicep while they thread the line to the main artery?????????  Horrible!!!!!! Jenn - June 2009 IDC-TN, Stage III, 02/2011 Stage IV mets to the lungs & spine / Laugh until your belly hurts, then laugh some more........... Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Tough few days - OUCH! jenn3 stephanief

Posts.Content: May 1, 2011 07:37PM jenn3 wrote: Okay.............because that wasn't enough.  I'll have to share what happened last night at the ER.  It's starting to get funny..........not. My fever spiked again and I knew that I'd have to go to the ER and get checked, which meant blood work AGAIN.  They were very quick in putting me into a room away from other patients in the waiting room and were extremely nice.  Here is the BUT............As the nurse was getting ready to draw blood.  I'm talking opened the sterile packaging, tied up my arm, needle so close to the arm you could hardly see the distance, but not yet touching another nurse walks in and says something I don't catch, my nurse says "no it's okay", "are you sure", "you're right, I'm coming now".  I thought, must be shift change and they're being really strict with the schedule.  I said "shift change", she said "no, my food was delivered - dinner".  Really????? We all (DH, DD and I) busted out laughing as she left the room.  And were still laughing when the other nurse came in for the draw.  Was she so starving that 2 more minutes would have been too long?  Seriously........I'm wondering is it me?????  I am sure going to have a lot to write up.  First the MRI done on the wrong area 6 weeks ago, that I decided not to do anything about, but think it'll be added to the list, the surgery and last night's ER visit.  I'm wondering ............Is it        ............The Twighlight Zone.........

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2011 03:19AM jenn3 wrote: Ann - I took Nexium prior to BC and find that it works well.  Medications like Nexium and Prilosec need to be taken daily in order to work.  On the rare occassions that I have break through heartburn I like Gaviscon the best, but will use Maalox or Rolaids if that's all that I can put my hands on.  But, taking Nexium daily really works! Posts.Content: jenn3 wrote: June 12 2009 - Mammogram June 16 2009 - Biopsies June 19 2009 - Diagnosis June 25 2009 - Surgery - BMX August 4 2009 - Chemo February 2 2010 (?) - Radiation March 16th - FINISHED IT ALL March 29th / 31st - CT scans / met with surgical onc and onc - given clean bill of health and PS name to discuss recon and made appt for 04/12 (will more than likely do DIEP) - follow up in 3 months.  I am finally finished with active treatment and can schedule recon at my convience. What a long journey this is starting 9 months ago.  I can remember back in June when I was given the dx and treatment plan thinking - this will never end.  Then starting chemo and thinking how miserable it was, but came here for support and was told over and over - I can do it.  And y'all were right I got through it - it is doable.  Not fun, but doable.  I did radiation, breezed through it only to have the ending a little rougher than I thought, but again I got through it with your support and understanding.  I know I'll need continued support, but wanted to thank all of you for your support, knowledge and understanding.  I still have some recovering to do, but am looking forward to getting back to life and ......exercising regularly again.   To all of my Stage III exercise and weight loss sisters I really don't have any excuses now.  Time to walk, bike or find whatever I can to whip my butt back into shape...... Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2011 06:29PM jenn3 wrote: Welcome and I am so sorry you had to find your way here.  I am TN and have mets to the lungs and spine, but don't have extensive mets to my spine as your wife does, I only have two vertabre that have been affected.  I take Xgeva rather than Zometa to strengthen the bones.  Xgeva is given in shot form once a month rather than IV, which I think is the only difference.   The chemo I am currently on is Gemzar/Carboplatin, which has worked to shrink the tumors as of my last scans.  I'll continue on this chemo regimine until it no longer works. I just had bone cement put in to lift the compressed vertabre.  My procedure was an outpatient procedure.  There are other surgical procedures for the spine that are similar, but are more involved when there is more of the spine innvolved.  Jenn

Posts.Content: jenn3 wrote: It seems the reality of what I'm dealing with is really starting to hit. I find myself crying at the drop of a hat, tearing up everytime I talk about "it" and feel like the world is spinning around me while I'm standing still.  And.........the pain is just unrelenting, which isn't helping.   The portion of the spine that was so painful is much better, but the pain in my ribs, muscle spasms and upper spine is horrible.  I've been trying to "handle" it by taking my pain meds every 3 - 5 hours, working, radiation, home, bills and family obligations.  Last night was the icing on the cake - I had a huge meltdown.  Because, that wasn't enough my DD, who is away in school called because she was having a severe migraine, with deafness and numbness on her left side.  She ended up in the ER with a slew of test because she does have a rare neurological disease and they needed to be sure it wasn't a flare up - "luckily" it was a migraine. I went into the office today, talked to my boss and co-workers and am taking off a few days to a week, to do nothing, something or nothing again. I also made a phone call to my onc and let him know I just can't handle the pain - I need more help. He was so nice on the phone, understanding and made me feel better.  He gave me 12 hour medicine to take and said to continue what I'm taking for breakthrough pain.  I am terrified of the long acting medicine, but I just took it.  I already feel better mentally knowing I have some time off from work with no plans.  I can just relax. Jenn - June 2009 IDC-TN, Stage III, 02/2011 Stage IV mets to the lungs & spine / Laugh until your belly hurts, then laugh some more........... Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: ANOTHER Meltdown.... jenn3 MCTHO

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2010 12:53PM jenn3 wrote: I have always suffered with allergies, exercise induced asthma and sinus problems.  It sounds like you have fluid that is stuck in the sinus cavity/ear canals.  Like previously mentioned a decongestant is helpful.  I also find that Mucinex helps - if the mucus is thick the Mucinex helps to thin it out so that it can drain.  Lastly - something like Afrin with a small steroid dose helps open the passage ways.  If you do use Afrin or a like product, use if for a brief time, it can be addictive and ruin your sinus cavity with long term use (daily for months, years).   If all else fails go see the ENT, they can clean you out right in the office.

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2011 08:30AM jenn3 wrote: Thank you all so much for your support.......I was terrified of feeling loopy on this 12 hour medicine, but I don't.  The onc said it would take about 2 days to really notice a difference, but I noticed a big difference last night.  He also told me that he was starting me off on a really low dose and if I was still having pain by Monday to let him know (let him know either way). I can get disability, actually my disability package is much better than I thought.  But, I am afraid.  I've worked since I was 14 years old......I wanted to earn extra money so my friend and I went to the neighborhood po-boy shop in the summer and convinced the owner to let us serve softdrinks for free lunch and $10, then onto babysitting, then "real" jobs.  I guess I'm holding out because, well I don't know why...........  Surely I need to see the upside of not working and receiving a paycheck.  I could become a "lady of leisure".
Posts.Title: ANOTHER Meltdown.... jenn3 MCTHO

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2011 08:39PM jenn3 wrote: Elizabeth/Lowrider - thank you!  I do love my job, it's a happy place filled with support, friendship and love.  But, family is more important.  Hopefully these new pain meds will help ease the pain enough that I can make a rational decision.  I talked to my Mom today and told her what I was thinking and DH will support me either way...........like you said it is a tough decision to make. Today was nice.  Although I didn't feel loopy, I didn't want to drive because I'm sure my reflexes are not 100% when taking meds.  My mom picked me up @ 11:30am, we had a guilt free lunch of seafood gumbo and split a lunch platter of fish, shrimp and oysters - even splitting the food we couldn't finish it.  Then we went to the mall so that I could get my DH his Bday present for tomorrow.  I also treated myself to a watch I've been eyeing up for over a year and some DKNY-Pure body cream (my favorite new scent).  After shopping we stopped at a wonderful "fancy" bakery and had delicious deserts that I can't pronouce, then hung out with my sister for the rest of the afternoon and did a little shopping in her closets (which is fun, she has tons of stuff)............ending it with boiled crawfish from my favorite seafood place.  I had a wonderful day!  And.......the pain was minimal until I hit the 9 hour mark of my 12 hour medicine, it increased, but I made it through using my other meds.  I know the onc said it would take about two days or that he may need to increase the dose because he was giving me a low dose, but I do notice a difference in the pain already.  Last night there was a period of about an hour or so in which I felt absolutely no pain, nothing, nada......it was so nice!!!!
Posts.Title: ANOTHER Meltdown.... jenn3 MCTHO

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2011 09:11PM jenn3 wrote: Thank all of you for your support, it really helps coming from people that understand. Today I woke up hurting as usual, took my 12 hour meds with my 4 hour meds and didn't feel real pain again for 8 hours, it was amazing.  I was a little tired feeling around 10am, 4 hours after taking my meds, then again around 2 - 3p when the pain starting kicking in, but Wow - 8 hours without miserable pain.  And..........thank goodness it was a no pain/low pain day because it was DH's birthday and I wanted it to be about him all day, and it was.

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2010 10:10AM jenn3 wrote: Kimber - we've been several times to Disney and love it.  We've always gone the week of July 4th because my husband is a track official and they work the big track meet held at Disney - the prelims for the Jr Olymics.  Needless to say Disney is really busy that week.  My friend at work, whom we've made fun of for his obessive organization on a Disney trip turned me onto a site that tells you the best times to visit each park, etc.  I believe the cost is $15-20 to join, but well worth it.  I think it's called Mike's Tour Guide - if you're interested I'll look up the correct information.  We finally decided to use this website and I kid you not, the week of July 4th the longest wait we had at any park was 10 minutes.  Some parks we went on rides 3 and 4 times in a row with no wait.  This company/person really has it down to a science and we no longer make fun of my friend, because it really works.  This may help you see more without without wearing you out too much. Disney truly is magical....................all of your troubles seem to disappear at the gate.

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2011 09:31PM jenn3 wrote: Good for all of you that have stood up to the handicap abusers.  I didn't park in the handicap spots, but in all honesty didn't realize how difficult it can be using a regular spot trying to get in and out of the car with a wheelchair or crutches.  DD#2 was ill for several months requiring a wheelchair, then crutches and it infuriated me when someone healthy without a permit parked in the handicap places and we had to manuever in a regular place.  DD#2 started to feel better after a few months and started having good days mixed with the bad days and always on the good days asked me to park elsewhere and that was during the Christmas season.  She has her morales in the right place.  And.........by the way her Christmas present to us that year was to walk again. I now have a handicap permit and only use it when I'm having a bad day or a day I know I need to park close.  If I'm having a good day or even a bad day, but I know I can still park close without using a handicap spot I park elsewhere.  I worry that there will be someone else who needs the place more than I do, especially someone with a wheelchair, motorized chair, walker, crutches or an elderly person who needs more space and doesn't have the ability to walk very far without sitting or taking a break. Again, Kudos to you for standing up to the weasels that tried or did park in the handicap place.

Posts.Title: Leukine put me down for 24 hours CoolBreeze jenn3

Posts.Content: jenn3 wrote: Monday, I had my first chemo of gemzar/carbo.  I had to do the chemo though the vein because my port surgery wasn't scheduled until the next day.  That's fine, I'll have it for the next round.  Whew......that Gemzar stung, but nothing that wasn't helped with a warm pack while it was going in.   It was a long day, with labs, onc and chemo.  Came home, felt pretty good, watched television went to bed.  Woke up the next morning feeling a bit uneasy, but not queasy or nauseated.  However, my port surgery was scheduled so I couldn't eat or drink anything.  Sprite would have worked wonders.  Then the hospital calls and tells me they have a brain aneurysm surgery scheduled before me that may run late, delay coming in by an hour.  I got there and still had to wait another 4 hours before my surgery began.  It's all good, I'm still not complaining or upset, I get it.  I went through all of my current medications with the nurse and then told her of my concerns with the "happy" drugs because of the medication I'm taking.  She assured me it was't a problem.   WELL..........GUESS WHAT????? Something went terribly wrong!!!  As they were hooking me up, prepping my arm I turned my head sideways and closed my eyes going into relax mode.  They shot me with some numbing medication, which is when I opened my eyes and let them know I was in pain and still wide awake.  The nurse then tells the radiologist doing the procedure, I thought she was asleep, I gave her Versaid.  I said nope, I'm not asleep IT'S HURTING, they gave me the rest of the Fentenyl and by now I am hysterical and can feel EVERYTHING.  I can feel the coil going up the vein, hear the sounds, feel the tugging, etc.........I was hysterical, but the didn't stop.  They claimed to have even given me another vial of Fentenyl.    Something didn't work.  I was straight as an arrow by the time they rolled me into recovery.  So much so, I walked out 10 minutes later with my instructions in hand.   I woke up the next morning in so much pain, muscles spasms, stiffness and overall pain I went hysterical again.  And...........I was running 102 fever.  I took a double dose of pain meds, went into the hospital and had to have cultures done of the port area, blood work and blood cultures, plus my neupogen shot.  Holy Moly Guacamole...... I couldn't speak without crying I was in so much pain.  My youngest DD said it was the first time she'd ever seen me like that - I'd have to agree. From that point to my family kept me on a strict every 4 hour pain medication regime so that it wouldn't get out of control again (even in the wee hours of the morning).   Honestly, I think for whatever reason, I didn't get the drugs via IV, there must have been a blockage.  Then, I was in so much pain that my entire body tensed up so much while my arm was strapped to the table that a nerve was pinched in my neck and shoulder, of course terrible back spasms and because the pain was off the wall my nerves were pissed and everything hurt.    Slowly, I am feeling better, but I will never EVER go through that again if I can help it.  The hospital director will be getting a letter and maybe a phone call on this one, in addition to another problem I had.  I just can't believe a facility this big with so many accolades let me go through such a barbaric procedure. Can you imagine, having nothing for pain other than one freakin' local numbing shot while having a port inserted into your bicep while they thread the line to the main artery?????????  Horrible!!!!!! Jenn - June 2009 IDC-TN, Stage III, 02/2011 Stage IV mets to the lungs & spine / Laugh until your belly hurts, then laugh some more........... Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: May 1, 2011 01:21PM jenn3 wrote: Each day is getting better.  The tension in my muscles from the spasms have let go and are giving way...........thank goodness.  Last night I really had my first good night sleep in a long time - much needed. I already started the letter I'm going to write and I  will let everyone know what I went through.  Usually Versed helps you to forget, but here I am almost 6 days out and I still remember everything, very clearly.  I'm not sure what happened, but it did and wasn't taken care of.  I am so disappointed in the doctors and nurses that performed this surgery and hope that if anything good can come of this, it will be a good learning experience for others.

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2012 12:16PM jenn3 wrote: I am also TN and found that looking for answers for and info on TNBC was harder than other types of cancer.  I found that I got more information here.  There is also another good information to be had on tnbcfoundation.org , but still like BCO better.  To answer your question about TN being more dangerous.  "They", the powers that be to say that having TN is not good and has a higher death rate.  But my belief is that cancer of any kind is a crap shoot.  So, having TN is the same thing, we just don't know how or when our day will come. I look forward to hearing from you soon and am sending big (((hugs))) until then.  Jenn
Posts.Title: Stage IV and Triple Negative kokonut Heidihill

Posts.Content: jenn3 wrote: Last week was a fairly good week for me.  I was able to clean house, do laundy, cook almost everynight, which I enjoy doing for my family and I was tired of out to eat meals, other than our great dinner for our annniversary. I was also able to get out for fun getting a mani-pedi, meet friends for lunch, and get errands done.  I'm sure I over did because I felt good and didn't want to pass on feeling well. I woke up Saturday not feeling bad, but not feeling good anymore.  I pretty much slept off and on all day watching television, other than cooking a dish to bring to my cousins for Easter. I woke up Sunday feeling the same way as the day before, but emotionally happier because it was Easter. I took it easy until it was time to leave. The we jumped in the car and took the hour drive to her house. That was when I started to feel bad. DH thinks because of the brain mets and some swelling (possibly) that I developed slight motion sickness. Anyway, after celebrating Easter and another hour drive home I wasn't feeling well at all.  Typically when I feel bad my emotions take over. I guess DH suspected something was wrong because when I announced I was going to bed and left the room, he followed me to the room to find out if I was okay and that was it, I couldn't hold it in anymore. The tears just started flowing and wouldn't stop. I told him I was just tired, not just physically, but tired.  Tired of people not realizing I am sick. Other than bloat face/body, which is ugly and I hate.  I still function so I know it's hard, but seriously don't people get it? Cancer doesn't mean curling up in bed and waiting to die anymore.  I'm tired of no longer be able to run errands when I want to run an errand, tired of not being able to jump up from a seating position without walking off.  I have to take my time AND use a da#n walker or wheelchair.  This time I'm tired of NO HAIR.  I just tired of it, but I'm stil in for the fight and won't give up, I'm just TIRED of it. Then as I sat there crying, snot nosed and feeling sorry for myself I remembered I have drugs for these times.  I took a Xanax, stopped crying and just talked to my DH about "stuff".  The Xanax kicked in and I started to feel better.  Don't know why I'm sharing this, but I am.  Does this happen to you from time to time? How do you handle?  Do you get angry, sad or both? Jenn Jenn - June 2009 IDC-TN, Stage III, 02/2011 Stage IV mets to the lungs & spine / Laugh until your belly hurts, then laugh some more........... Posts.Content: jenn3 wrote: I really haven't shared much about my youngest daughter and some of our tough times here, but she just called with an award she received that is such an honor I have to share how she got to it.  Two years ago she was a healthy normal teenager (sophmore), then after a cheerleading performance the first week of school she starting having pain in her foot.  We thought she had sprained her ankle and treated it as such, it didn't get better went to the doctor they took x-rays and various test, didn't see anything and suggested a boot.  Again, got worse - more testing, nothing..... Then this mysterious pain and inability to move her foot went to both feet - she was suddenly in a wheelchair - a month later it was in her hands and she was unable to even bathe or brush her own teeth.  Again...... doctors don't know what it is.  She pushes through - still attending school, her friends helping her with her work, teachers giving oral test instead of written.  She works hard in therapy and manages to get out of the wheelchair, but still struggles with pain. One year later she is diagnosed with a rare neurological disease that is treatable.  She hobbles through the next year trying different medications, learning to manage the disease, but is unable to cheer anymore, which disappoints her, but you do what you have to in life.  During this time, she continues to volunteer at the Lighthouse for the Blind, continues to do various other volunteer work with Key Club and maintains honor roll status.  Then......... the fall of last year her dad passes away and early summer I'm diagnosed with Stage III Breast Cancer. The start of her Senior year she has to deal with the death of a parent and the cancer diagnosis of another in addition to Senior year stress.  Does she give up?  Nope, she works just as hard with her volunteer work, helps more around the house and manages to get her grades up even higher!!!  And.............her hard work has started to pay off with scholarships she's being offered to various colleges, but that's not all............ She was nominated by her peers for Louisiana Young Heros Award - an award given literally to only handful of kids each year.  The committee interviewed her teachers and school administrators, talked to various other people she's worked with and she has WON the award.  My sweet angel will be one of a few select kids in the State to receive this award and will be honored with a luncheon at the Govenor's Mansion in April (by which time I hope to have more hair).  I am so proud of her............. She has overcome so much in the last few years and has ended up on top!!!!  Amazing what our kids can do when they put their minds to it.  I am so proud of her and just wanted to share it with my BC Sisters. Jenn - June 2009 IDC-TN, Stage III, 02/2011 Stage IV mets to the lungs & spine / Laugh until your belly hurts, then laugh some more........... Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: jenn3 wrote: I am 1 year and 4 months out from dx and 6 months from active treatment.  I am starting to feel better, life is getting filled with "busy" stuff again and it's good.  But......I still feel different.  There are many days I still feel like the cancer patient when I look in the mirror and still feel the need to come here and offer advice, kind words or a funny.  I also find that as life moves on I feel disconnected from the BC as well.  I will sit down after a full day of work, errands and what not and realize that BC didn't cross my mind and I didn't jump on breastcancer.org - then I feel guilty for not checking in to offer words of advice or a (((hug))) to someone in need.  I also find that I really really don't want to talk about it to my friends, family and coworkers.  I don't want to discuss my curly hair, reconstruction or how often I go for check ups or how will I know if I've had a recurrance.  I just don't want to discuss it, I'm ready to move on..............I think???? I needed to say this out loud and share my feelings and wonder - do you feel this way too? Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2011 12:01PM jenn3 wrote: I think MD Anderson is a great facility and has a lot to offer.  I did look into it, but as it turned out for me it doesn't make a difference in treatment - at least not right now.  My onc offered to help me with getting a second opinion at MD or any other facility of my choosing before I started treatment (for triple negative).  After talking to different people and looking at what other triple negative patients were being offered, he was offering me the same chemo options and trials as what I would have been offered at MD.  I made the decision not to make the trip to MD.  Not that the decision won't change down the road, but for now I feel that I'm being offered all that there is available.  I am at a big facility and my case is not only handled by my onc, but reviewed from time to time at their weekly board meetings where they discuss various patients, which makes me feel comfortable in my treatment plan. I know it's a hard decision and I wish you luck.  (((hugs))) Jenn

Posts.Title: Stage III Recently Diagnosed What are Your Issues? Shanagirl Shanagirl

Posts.Content: jenn3 wrote: Last week was a fairly good week for me.  I was able to clean house, do laundy, cook almost everynight, which I enjoy doing for my family and I was tired of out to eat meals, other than our great dinner for our annniversary. I was also able to get out for fun getting a mani-pedi, meet friends for lunch, and get errands done.  I'm sure I over did because I felt good and didn't want to pass on feeling well. I woke up Saturday not feeling bad, but not feeling good anymore.  I pretty much slept off and on all day watching television, other than cooking a dish to bring to my cousins for Easter. I woke up Sunday feeling the same way as the day before, but emotionally happier because it was Easter. I took it easy until it was time to leave. The we jumped in the car and took the hour drive to her house. That was when I started to feel bad. DH thinks because of the brain mets and some swelling (possibly) that I developed slight motion sickness. Anyway, after celebrating Easter and another hour drive home I wasn't feeling well at all.  Typically when I feel bad my emotions take over. I guess DH suspected something was wrong because when I announced I was going to bed and left the room, he followed me to the room to find out if I was okay and that was it, I couldn't hold it in anymore. The tears just started flowing and wouldn't stop. I told him I was just tired, not just physically, but tired.  Tired of people not realizing I am sick. Other than bloat face/body, which is ugly and I hate.  I still function so I know it's hard, but seriously don't people get it? Cancer doesn't mean curling up in bed and waiting to die anymore.  I'm tired of no longer be able to run errands when I want to run an errand, tired of not being able to jump up from a seating position without walking off.  I have to take my time AND use a da#n walker or wheelchair.  This time I'm tired of NO HAIR.  I just tired of it, but I'm stil in for the fight and won't give up, I'm just TIRED of it. Then as I sat there crying, snot nosed and feeling sorry for myself I remembered I have drugs for these times.  I took a Xanax, stopped crying and just talked to my DH about "stuff".  The Xanax kicked in and I started to feel better.  Don't know why I'm sharing this, but I am.  Does this happen to you from time to time? How do you handle?  Do you get angry, sad or both? Jenn Jenn - June 2009 IDC-TN, Stage III, 02/2011 Stage IV mets to the lungs & spine / Laugh until your belly hurts, then laugh some more........... Posts.Content: jenn3 wrote: My onc called with the results of my most recent MRI scan and it looks like I am a candidate for the bone cement to be put in where I have the collapsed vertabre @ T8 or T6 - can't remember at the moment.  I was so excited because the pain has gotten so bad.  He and I decided we would do the surgery the week I came back from vacation, which would be the week of the 25th.  However, the doctor that will perform the surgery is on vacation until Aug 1st and the onc doesn't want to do chemo until after the surgery.   The Gemzar really knocks my RBC & platelets down and he doesn't want me to have problems with the surgery.  I understand, but as a TN patient I am terrified to be off of chemo for 3 or more weeks.  As it is I was going to be off one week because of my vacation, but to be off until after surgery seems like a long break, especially for a TN patient.  I almost feel like not having the surgery just so that I can have the chemo - who would have thought I'd say those words? I know we can't give medical advice to one another because we're not drs, but what would you do in this situation? Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2009 12:35PM jenn3 wrote: Everyone here has given wonderful advice and I really don't know if I could add much more.  I was where you were in June of this year.  Found the lump, went in for a mammogram, biopsies, still not taking it seriously, two weeks later BMX, 6/7 weeks later chemo, which is where I still am.  I understand exactly what you're saying about hearing the "C" word.  Once the onc said "cancer" I didn't hear much of anything else being said, like you all I heard was blah, blah, blah, you'll be fine, blah, blah, blah, surgery, blah, blah, chemo........... Some of what was said stuck because I remember waking up the next day and hitting the internet with what I remembered and the pathology reports from the biopsies.  After the biopsies I was told they thought it was stage 2, but they wouldn't be able to give me the offical stage until after surgery.  In may case it did move to stage 3.  The official staging comes with the surgery once they can determine the true size of the tumor, node involvement and so on.     Love the hair idea, I should have thought of that.  I also have to comment on the udder/cow thing you mentioned on the mammo biopsies.  My co-worker mooed at me when I left the office to have my mammo biopsies and said "enjoy".  The whole time I was laying there with my boob hanging out under the table all I could think of was her mooing at me.  LOL............ Keep that sense of humor, mine has kept me from going crazy.  Surround yourself with supportive people and now is the time to start letting people help you.  You will get through this ............  Jenn

Posts.Title: Kind of Confused Priscilla0929 jenrio

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2010 10:56AM jenn3 wrote: I posted on this thread once and lost it.  I can so relate to the pain issues.  I have AS(anklosing spondolysis) along with a bulging disk, a fissure in the disk above (losing fluid) and bone spurs up and down my spine and hips from the AS.  I am in constant pain and because I "suck it up" it's hard for the doctors to really understand how bad it truly is.   I had a complete breakdown for the first time about a month ago in the doctors office and I think that was the first time he had seen me "lose it".  He did help me, but I really need to figure out a steady medication not the every now and then medication, shots and facet blocks.  I am currently taking Vit D3, Calicum, Fosmax, Indomethican, Methotrexate, a muscle relaxer that is new and can't remember the name and Tramadol - still suffer, suffer, suffer.  In addition to eating asprin like candy on the bad days. They've tried me on Lyrica and Neurontin, but my legs and ankles swelled up like little ballons (couln't get my shoes on).  I know its wrong, but when the pain is there I can't sit, stand, lay down - I am a total wreck.  Recently I had one bad night, even took benedryl to try to make me sleepy, didn't work, got up and layed on the floor in the living room, extra bedroom, heating pad on the sofa, ice packs, rolled on the ball trying to stretch the spine and finally at 4am fell asleep - it was awful and I was in tears.  I had to follow up that night by going to work the next day - can you imagine?  There are days I envision ripping my spine out of my skin.......... Chronic pain is so hard for our friends and family to understand and if someone hasn't suffered with it they really don't understand it. I think doctors also don't know what to do and are so afraid to over prescribe and/or turn patients into addicts that they don't work with the patient in the way that they should.  (((HUGS))) to all of you and my heart goes out to each and everyone of you that is suffering. Hopefully there will come the day when pain is no longer misunderstood and chronic inflammatory diseases is more understood.

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2012 10:04AM jenn3 wrote: I grew up going to church every Sunday, my grandparents had a very strong faith.  Times were hard for my mom, sister and me so as a teen I questioned God a lot and complained "why me".  Ironically, as I got older and started to rebel and not go to church unless I was truly forced I realized that the universe and God aren't about me, there's more.  My Grandfather once told me, "God doesn't create miracles, he gave us life so that we can create the miracles of medicine, engineering, etc".  I actually understood what he was telling me. I don't pray for the miracle of a cure, but I do pray for the strength to handle life as it is now, to handle the treatments, patience, the people around me.

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2011 02:50PM jenn3 wrote: I haven't been here in a while, I forgot to add it to my favorites. I may be too late, but wanted to add that when you go for long periods of time without a good nights sleep (REM cycle) you adjust.  However, when you do finally go into a deep sleep/REM cycle you will have terrible, vivid dreams, but they will subside.  Keep trying the Melatonin.  I was given the sleep information when I had trouble years ago, then again when my daughter struggled with her neuro disease.  Barb - I am so sorry for all that you're going through. I love your sense of humor and insight on various subjects - I can't believe you aren't surrounded by friends.   There was a question asked about auto-immune, are we angry that it has taken so much.  I am not angry with it.  I feel that it is what it is and learned to live with limits.  However, I do find when my pain gets out of control I don't think clearly and I get very frustrated with my situation. Hope everyone is having a good day - I'm adding this to my favorites so it doesn't get lost on me.....
